excerpts: I ordered the Omakase Don along with their daily special:
Omakase Don: the bowl have 12 pc of fresh sashimi and sushi rice/ comes with seaweed and wasabi/soy sauce.
omakase don.author: Sammi L.
omakase don.review:
いらっしゃいませ！

Kaisen DON defines Chirashi bowls to me. Came here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was packed. Every table were seated and I see that every table had at least one Omakase Don- so I knew I had to order that! I ordered the Omakase Don along with their daily special: Truffle with Scallops. 

Omakase Don: the bowl have 12 pc of fresh sashimi and sushi rice/ comes with seaweed and wasabi/soy sauce.

Truffle with Scallops: 4 pcs of scallops topped with tobiko and truffle

Overall, the sashimi was fresh but the cut can be more generous. The concept of this place is not bad since they are mainly serving the fresh fish/bowls or hot bowls such as unagi don, salmon ochazuke don, gyu don and etc. If you like chirashi- I recommend coming here! For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.

excerpts: The Omakase Don was amazing; it had fresh & yummy pieces of sashimi, and the sashimi to rice ratio was also perfect!
So even though this place is a little more on the pricey side, you get a good amount of the quality sashimi that you're paying for.
omakase don.author: Kathy Y.
omakase don.review:
Kaisen Don is a quaint little family-owned sushi restaurant, bringing you delicious chirashi bowls!
The Omakase Don was amazing; it had fresh & yummy pieces of sashimi, and the sashimi to rice ratio was also perfect! So even though this place is a little more on the pricey side, you get a good amount of the quality sashimi that you're paying for.

excerpts:
Good Omakase Don place!

We both got Omakase Don - Chef's choices 12 pieces ($28.95) which came with Uni, salmon, tuna, hamachi, tamago, fish roe, crab meats, cucumber and seaweed.
omakase don.author: Clare L.
omakase don.review:
Good Omakase Don place!

We got here around 5:30 on Sunday night and we were the first customers! We both got Omakase Don - Chef's choices 12 pieces ($28.95) which came with Uni, salmon, tuna, hamachi, tamago, fish roe, crab meats, cucumber and seaweed.

Fish was fresh and tasty but I felt that there were too much rice in a bowl. I wish there is less rice and bigger pieces of fish. Nonetheless, it was good. Uni tastes amazing! I checked in on yelp to get free edamame which was okay but good for free appetizer. Also, their tea was unexpectedly good. 

I recommend this place!

excerpts: We ordered a few items: Omakase Don, Hamachi Don and Blue Fin Tuna.
Food looked good and tasted fresh for the most part.
omakase don.author: Roman L.
omakase don.review:
We came to this place to see what people have been talking about. We ordered a few items: Omakase Don, Hamachi Don and Blue Fin Tuna. Food looked good and tasted fresh for the most part. Our stomachs weren't happy afterwards so doubt that we will be coming back anytime soon. 

Pros:
Food presentation can look good on instagram.

Cons:
Way too much rice.
Not worth the price point.
Service can be improved. (It's extremely awkward and rude for them to stand over your shoulder as you try to figure out how much tip you want to leave!)

This was our personal experience and thoughts, though others may feel different. All in all, we won't be rushing back anytime soon and probably won't be recommending to friends or family.

excerpts: My main was the rainbow don and the SO got the omakase don.
Both of our dons tasted very fishy and overall we felt that the fish was not very fresh.
omakase don.author: Andrea K.
omakase don.review:
The SO and I are absolute sushi lovers and were disappointed with our experience. The service was alright-- it was sometimes difficult to flag down a waiter/waitress as the two people working that night were chatting by the registers. 

We started with a scallop burger and blue fin sashimi. The uni in the scallop burger had a funky flavor that completely overpowered the scallops and the blue fin was very fishy and not melt-in-your-mouth tender. My main was the rainbow don and the SO got the omakase don. Both of our dons tasted very fishy and overall we felt that the fish was not very fresh. There was a decent fish to rice proportion but I ended up eating a lot of the rice to cover up the fishy flavor. 

I'm hoping that my one experience was just an off day and I'd like to try it out again in the future... but it's just a bit on the pricier end for sushi.

excerpts: Most of the time, I order the Omakase Don
and it's always creative and fresh.
Last time, in addition to the medley of beautiful seafood atop a perfectly cooked bowl of rice, it came with a small slice of foie gras.
Another time, it came with truffled scallops.
omakase don.author: Tala D.
omakase don.review:
Updated: Changed my rating from 4 to 5 stars as I've been there a bunch more times since my review and the food is awesome every time. Super consistent and so much fresh uni!!!!

Kaisen Don is a fantastic little chirashi joint that I have wished into existence. Chirashi is my favorite way to eat sushi.

I have been here 3-4 times. Most of the time, I order the Omakase Don and it's always creative and fresh. Last time, in addition to the medley of beautiful seafood atop a perfectly cooked bowl of rice, it came with a small slice of foie gras. Another time, it came with truffled scallops. Always comes with a spot of uni and is so delectable.

The presentation and plating of the sushi here is a clear indication that the chefs in the kitchen know what they're doing and care about their craft. Everything is so artful and pretty, it's hard to dig in!

I wish they sold a simple beer here, such as Sapporo or Orion. I'm guessing they don't have an on-sale beer and wine license.

Kaisen Don is priced fairly for the quality and quantity of food.

Keep up the good work, Kaisen!

excerpts: We ordered the omakase don, the rainbow don, and the kaisen spoon.
All were completely delicious.
The omakase don had a good variety of fish and a great rice ratio.
Super fresh and tasty.
Same with the rainbow don.
omakase don.author: Yanni L.
omakase don.review:
This place is delicious and full of noms! We ordered the omakase don, the rainbow don, and the kaisen spoon. All were completely delicious. The omakase don had a good variety of fish and a great rice ratio. Super fresh and tasty. Same with the rainbow don. The kaisen spoon (which I believe has oyster, ikura, tobiko, and ponzu sauce) was really flavorful and a perfect portion size.

Service was great and the complimentary tea was surprisingly tasty. The complimentary edamame (check-in with Yelp) was decent and nothing special but nice for a small, free appetizer. 

Can't wait to go back!

excerpts: Ordered the omakase don.
omakase don.author: Elaine C.
omakase don.review:
I'm a huge fan of omakase and charashi... so this place was perfect! 

I came here right before closing and was able to get seated. Ordered the omakase don. Each meal comes with a miso soup. 

Food came out pretty quickly and I was in love with the presentation- especially the wasabi. I'm not a fan of wasabi so I had to pick it off :(

The bowl itself was delicious! Everything was hand-picked by the chef! My favorite was the uni, salmon and toro. The quality of everything was very fresh. 

The rice however was mushy. 

I will definitely come back regardless of parking and the rice. It's on ocean so street parking is all metered unless you find a residential spot. It's all worth the drive for the quality of fish. I left with a fully belly and smile on my face :)

excerpts: I ordered the Omakase Don ($28.95):
my Omakase don was topped with Mirugai (geoduck),
Hamachi (yellowtail), Ikura (salmon roe),
Uni (sea urchin), Hotate (scallop), Sake (salmon torched), Amaebi (raw shrimp, no head), Kani w/ its brain (crab leg w/ torched brain), and Tamago (sweet egg omelet).
For the value driven folks, the cuts of fish (~12 slices) are thicker than usual for a chirashi.
During their soft opening, the toppings for the omakase don were run-of-the-mill fish like maguro, hamachi, and sake.
omakase don.author: Cherylynn N.
omakase don.review:
New restaurant opening excitement gets the best of some of us. I'm one of the biggest offenders but I'm glad I waited on Kaisen Don.

Kaisen Don soft opened about 3 months ago in the former Rainbow T Dessert space. It's a small restaurant with seating for about 20 people so it's not a place to come rolling in with your entire posse of 10. It's ideal for solo diners and couples. No reservations.   

Kaisen Don's specialty is chirashi with about 10 variations. For those squeamish about raw fish, they have dons with cooked proteins: chicken teriyaki, unagi, chashu, and beef curry. Each order comes with a complimentary bowl of miso soup. Currently, they don't have a liquor license. 

If you see a particular item on their Yelp page that you want, call before visiting. I saw a pic of the shaved ankimo but they didn't have it and the girl at the table in back of me wanted negitoro but they didn't have that either. 

Note to the owner, there's a small discrepancy on your Yelp page. It says, to mention Yelp to get 20% off but the grand opening check-in offer is 10% off. 

Last week, I had some time to kill because of street cleaning in my area so I figured it was the perfect time to visit Kaisen Don.

I ordered the Omakase Don ($28.95): http://bit.ly/2H8jKfF. The fish and seafood toppings will vary daily and based on seasonality. 

On the day, I visited my Omakase don was topped with Mirugai (geoduck), Hamachi (yellowtail), Ikura (salmon roe), Uni (sea urchin), Hotate (scallop), Sake (salmon torched), Amaebi (raw shrimp, no head), Kani w/ its brain (crab leg w/ torched brain), and Tamago (sweet egg omelet). For the value driven folks, the cuts of fish (~12 slices) are thicker than usual for a chirashi. Small sheets of nori are provided so you can make mini hand rolls. 

(+) Good variety with some premium offerings like mirugai and uni. Remember I said, I was glad I waited on visiting Kaisen Don? During their soft opening, the toppings for the omakase don were run-of-the-mill fish like maguro, hamachi, and sake. Didn't see premium offerings. 

(+) Everything was super fresh with my favorite being the perfectly sweet and briny Santa Barbara uni. So good. 

(-) Knife skills could be improved. Several slices didn't have clean edges (i.e. amaebi). 

(-) While the sushi rice was a good temperature and texture, it was underseasoned and plain. 

(-) The wasabi was awful quality (dry, crumbly texture). Yes, it has their cute embossed fish logo but I hope the owner looks into using higher quality wasabi to match their fish.  

Service was polite and friendly. I was their first customer of the day and it took about 20 minutes for my order. 

Minimalist dining area with wooden tables and metal chairs. I enjoyed the 80s and 90s music they were playing. 

Looking at their pictures and their reviews for the past couple of months, it does seem Kaisen Don has some consistency issues and/or still trying to figure things out but I wouldn't be opposed to returning. Their raw fish is good quality and that's what's most important to me.

When I'm having a raw craving and don't want to spend $$$ on a nice sushi dinner or deal with the madness at Amami, Kaisen Don will do just fine.

excerpts:
Fresh sashimi - everything in our omakase don were de-lish especially the crab!
(+) They obviously put thought into the presentation of the donburi so that they are gram ready!
(+) 20% off during their grand opening!
omakase don.author: Tiffany U.
omakase don.review:
I'm always in the mood for sashimi so I knew I had to give Kaisen Don a try when I saw it pop up on Yelp! We were lucky enough to not have to wait at all- I could imagine that the wait times will change once people start hearing about this place. 

Here's what I liked:
(+) Fresh sashimi - everything in our omakase don were de-lish especially the crab!
(+) They obviously put thought into the presentation of the donburi so that they are gram ready!
(+) 20% off during their grand opening!
(+) UNI UNI UNI

Here's what I thought could use more work:
(-) The service was not terrible at all, but our waitress was a bit flustered and unorganized.
(-) The 1/2 tray of uni that we ordered didn't really come out in a half tray. It seems to be a smaller portion than what I'm used to, but it could very well be just perception because of the presentation. 

I think I'd definitely come back for more especially while they are still offering 20% off!

excerpts: Honestly I thought, the omakase don my sister ordered was a better deal.
omakase don.author: Derek L.
omakase don.review:
Don't get me wrong, I'm not a sushi hater.  I actually prefer fish over meat because its low in carbs and high in protein.  That equates to less time in the gym to burn off those calories.  

Unfortunately, the portion of rice to fish was excessive.  I would say a majority of the bowl was rice.  I ordered the kaisen don #1 and there were a few pieces of tamago, salmon, and ikura.  Honestly I thought, the omakase don my sister ordered was a better deal.  Especially with the 20% off.  

The yelp says their fish come from the Tsukiji market which is a well known fish trade port in Japan.  However, the preparation of their fish could be improved.  I felt like the texture wasn't firm enough and on the mushier side.  I was also very surprised to find a piece of bone that was still inside one of the yellow tail pieces.  It's fortunate that I didn't swallow the piece whole...

excerpts:
Seating is not great for large parties
Portion of rice is copious however inconsistency in cooking was a let down
Presentation of the fish was good and enjoyed the variety in the Omakase Don 

Overall Thoughts
omakase don.author: Eddie W.
omakase don.review:
3.5 Stars

Long story short

Seating is not great for large parties
Portion of rice is copious however inconsistency in cooking was a let down
Presentation of the fish was good and enjoyed the variety in the Omakase Don 

Overall Thoughts

If they can step up their rice game I could see myself coming back to try their other bowls

excerpts: This Omakase Don took me back to the day I went to Tsukiji Fish Market in Ginza.
omakase don.author: Jray M.
omakase don.review:
Thanks to @yelpsf for the recommendation. I have been wanting to try this new hot spot out and finally made the worthy Foodie Adventure thanks to @derjaymarz for visiting all the way from Germany and hungry SF Foodie @epumas.eats and @da.dan.chan for the company. This Omakase Don took me back to the day I went to Tsukiji Fish Market in Ginza. I went with homie, @kenikophoto, met a dope couple that shared their company and eduacated us about delicious fresh Uni.

Go and try this delicious bowl and utilize that soft opening 20% off.  

Larry the owner, opened up the door and me and my friend waited outside patiently. First one there I asked if he was the owner and he told us he was. It was nice to meet him and that now I know that there's a way more delicious spot than the other fish bowls nearby the area. Cost a little more but if you want to taste fish similar to what they have in Japan, GO HERE you will not be upset.

excerpts: I went with the omakase don because why wouldn't you want a little bit of everything?!
It came with salmon, tuna, yellowtail, octopus, salmon roe, and shrimp.
AND TO MY SURPRISE, uni and tamago!
I didn't even want to touch my bowl because of how beautiful it was.
omakase don.author: Christene M.
omakase don.review:
I love chirashi bowls so when I found out that this place opened up near my neighborhood I was so stoked to check it out. I went with the omakase don because why wouldn't you want a little bit of everything?! It came with salmon, tuna, yellowtail, octopus, salmon roe, and shrimp. AND TO MY SURPRISE, uni and tamago! I didn't even want to touch my bowl because of how beautiful it was. Each piece of fish and seafood was so fresh! 

For a new business, these guys know what they're doing. Service was great, I didn't feel rushed at all even though we stayed past their lunch hours (...sorry! But thank you again!!) I now found a new spot for when I have my cravings!

excerpts: - Omakase Don $29
While this don offers a h-u-g-e variety of fish & etc, the quality doesn't deliver.
The squid & scallop were also extremely disappointing - leaving a gross aftertaste in both of our mouths.
The rice was ok.
omakase don.author: Rachel Y.
omakase don.review:
The bf & I were pretty excited to try this place based on the reviews & the close distance from his home, but we were sadly disappointed by the quality & price.

FOOD:
- Omakase Don $29 
While this don offers a h-u-g-e variety of fish & etc, the quality doesn't deliver. The squid & scallop were also extremely disappointing - leaving a gross aftertaste in both of our mouths. The rice was ok.
- Rainbow Don $19
We ordered this based off of yelp reviews but don't be fooled. I didn't know a rainbow only had 3 colors.. but there were only 3 sashimi options offered with this & only 1 out of the 3 actually tasted decent.

ETC:
- Parking may be difficult, as it's on a very busy street.

Given that it seems like a fairly new restaurant, we might consider coming back.. or not. We'll see!

excerpts: I ordered the Omakase Don which looked beautiful, but for what it was was, I can't say that we were blown away by the quality nor the quantity of the bowl.
Like another yelper mentioned, the rice has too much vinegar and the rice to fish ratio was poor.
I know quality fresh seafood is pricey, and I expected that, but overall I can't say that the meal was memorable.
omakase don.author: Diane T.
omakase don.review:
Came here with the recommendation from a good friend. We showed up around 8pm on a tuesday night and was seated promptly. The restaurant is small, somewhat hidden amongst all the businesses on Ocean Avenue. It's right across the street from 24 hour as a marker. Probably not an ideal location for a big party. 

Overall, we would say that the meal was enjoyable. As someone that loves fresh fish and Chirashi style meals, I had really high hopes that Kaisen Don was going to live up to the hype.

Both the BF and I ordered the Omakase Don which looked beautiful, but for what it was was, I can't say that we were blown away by the quality nor the quantity of the bowl. Like another yelper mentioned, the rice has too much vinegar and the rice to fish ratio was poor. I know quality fresh seafood is pricey, and I expected that, but overall I can't say that the meal was memorable. I've definitely had more enjoyable chirashi dons at other places for better pricing and quality. 

Unfortunately, there was a very strong fish odor when you walk into the restaurant. I know, i know, it's a fresh sushi/sashimi restaurant, of course, it will smell like fish. However, the smell was overwhelming and a bit offputting. 

I believe the best thing we had that night was the scallop truffle burger. It tasted great..but I can't justify the price in the future. 

Would I come back? Probably if i felt like splurging. Would I recommend it to a friend? I'm not sure. Like I said, unfortunately, the meal was not memorable for me. What I do praise is the owner's passion for wanting to bring something he loved from Japan to here. The execution was a good homage to the bowls that we would eat in Japan and it's a great addition to Ocean. 

All in all, it's a local/private business that is worth checking out if you're okay with spending a little more on your meal for seafood.

excerpts: Omakase Don was $29 which has a variety of everything, including uni.
I personally thought it was way too much food.
omakase don.author: Kathleen N.
omakase don.review:
Delish and legit dons!

You are definitely tasting quality with every bite of fresh sashimi, sweet roe, and perfectly cooked sushi rice. 

The pricing is a bit steep, but you do get what you pay for! Omakase Don was $29 which has a variety of everything, including uni. I personally thought it was way too much food. I prefer to get the Hamachi Don ($16.95) which is smaller but oh-so delicious with healthy slices of hamachi and topped with a quarter bowl of sweet roe. 

I also tried the Scallop Burger ($9.99) which consisted of two pieces of scallops sandwiching uni and truffle butter. This was decent but wouldn't get again. 

The restaurant is pretty small with only 5 tables or so. I wouldn't bring a huge group as there is only one "big" table that can fit up to 6 people.

excerpts: They had scallops on special that night, so we went with one omakase don and a scallop don.
I have to say, the scallops were super fresh and sweet.
So good!
The rest of the fish was pretty good too, but I think I was expecting a little more in the omakase after paying $30.
Some other people mentioned this, but what took away from the dishes was the under-seasoned sushi rice and the addition of raw daikon in the don.
Both were bland and I avoided eating the daikon entirely.
It was more like it was put there to take up space in the bowl.
The wasabi was also really low quality, which took away from the taste of the fish.
omakase don.author: Jessica L.
omakase don.review:
Definitely not the best chirashi I've had, but not the worst either.

My friend and I wanted to check out Kaisen Don after seeing it on Instragram.  We found seats no problem on a Monday night at 7pm, but the restaurant is tiny, with only room for about 15 people.  I'd anticipate a wait on the weekend just because of the size of the restaurant.  

They had scallops on special that night, so we went with one omakase don and a scallop don.  I have to say, the scallops were super fresh and sweet.  So good!  The rest of the fish was pretty good too, but I think I was expecting a little more in the omakase after paying $30.  Some other people mentioned this, but what took away from the dishes was the under-seasoned sushi rice and the addition of raw daikon in the don.  Both were bland and I avoided eating the daikon entirely.  It was more like it was put there to take up space in the bowl.  The wasabi was also really low quality, which took away from the taste of the fish.  A lot of what makes a restaurant great is in the details.

Service is really great though, the waitress must have refilled our tea cups 10 times!  I'd be willing to come back if they did something about their wasabi and rice.

Tips and Tricks
-The K line will take you to almost right in front of the restaurant, pretty convenient!
-Almost everything is served as a donburi, not much variety in the menu

excerpts: We ordered Omakase don and Negitoro don and a Hamachi Kama.
I was expecting the Omakase don like the ones I see on pictures with crab
but I have the baby octopus instead,
and I thought for that price
, the baby octopus shouldn't be in that bowl and there should be a bit more quantity to the bowl.
omakase don.author: Cherry S.
omakase don.review:
Came here Thursday evening and there wasn't a line which is great. We ordered Omakase don and Negitoro don and a Hamachi Kama. 

I was expecting the Omakase don like the ones I see on pictures with crab but I have the baby octopus instead, and I thought for that price, the baby octopus shouldn't be in that bowl and there should be a bit more quantity to the bowl. However, the quality of the other fishes has wowed me enough, so I give it a 5 star. 

For the Negitoro don, it was the most expensive item on the menu, and we expected pieces of blue fin tuna toro bedded on top of sushi rice, but instead it was minced toro tuna. We thought chopping up the toro would be such a waste of a good fish, but surprisingly, the minced tuna rice and salmon roe and roasted seaweed flakes were a perfect combination, it was so good that we finished that bowl in just a sec. 

I also have to make a comment on their Salmon roe. The only time I had Salmon roe that is not fishy was the time when I travel in Japan. But this place rocks that Salmon Roe. IT IS NOT FISHY AT ALL. 

Lastly, the Hamachi kama was cooked perfectly. The portion is big and the meat are so tender and juicy. We usually will order Hamachi kama whenever we dine at Japanese restaurant, but never had any Hamachi Kama with this quality and size. 

We will definitely come back!

excerpts: We ordered an Omakase Don ($26.95) and a Gyu Don (13.95).
The Omakase Don had various types of fish, but it was your basics (tuna, salmon, hamachi, etc.).
The Gyu Don is pretty much a beef sukiyaki bowl.
The fish is fresh and sukiyaki is well made, not too salty and not too sweet.
However, there is a problem with both of these bowls - too much rice!
There was so much rice in the Omakase Don that half of the bowl was still full.
There was a lot of filler on the Omakase Don
omakase don.author: Nicholas H.
omakase don.review:
There aren't many chirashi places in San Francisco, so I was excited to see this place in my recommendations. TL;DR Despite the positive//negative reviews, try this place for yourself because you won't regret it!

It's a small restaurant with seating for only ~20 people so the wait may be longer than usual. I went in around 8:30 on a Friday and waited till 8:55 before getting a table for 2.

We ordered an Omakase Don ($26.95) and a Gyu Don (13.95). The Omakase Don had various types of fish, but it was your basics (tuna, salmon, hamachi, etc.). The Gyu Don is pretty much a beef sukiyaki bowl. The fish is fresh and sukiyaki is well made, not too salty and not too sweet. However, there is a problem with both of these bowls - too much rice! There was so much rice in the Omakase Don that half of the bowl was still full. There was a lot of filler on the Omakase Don - I truly hope they decide to add more fish on it, then the $26.95 would justify it.

Overall, I had a great experience here, the employees are friendly and pretty hardworking. I think that only two people work here and it can get overwhelming for them. If you're the manager, help them out and hire one more person!

excerpts: Had the sashimi omakase Don (I think).
Very tasty and well decorated.
omakase don.author: ben c.
omakase don.review:
Had the sashimi omakase Don (I think). Very tasty and well decorated. Good service and not too busy for lunch on a weekday. 

Need to stop by again. :)

excerpts: I got the Omakase Don $28.95 which included Tako, Hamachi, Salmon, Ikura, Tuna, Ebi, AND Uni.
The Uni wasn't specified in the menu or picture, but I got it anyways.
omakase don.author: Fiona L.
omakase don.review:
First place I wanted to try coming back home was Kaisen Don. Thank you Yelp. 

20% off Chirashi bowls? YES.
This means that the most bang for your buck is to order the most expensive one. And that's what I did. I got the Omakase Don $28.95 which included Tako, Hamachi, Salmon, Ikura, Tuna, Ebi, AND Uni. The Uni wasn't specified in the menu or picture, but I got it anyways. Merry Christmas to me! 

The restaurant is small and limited to small parties. The menu is simple as it comes with different kinds of dons (donburis). Although not stated in the menu, it comes with a bowl of mushroom miso soup which was a delightful start to the meal. 

The bowl takes quite a while to make as I'm sure they prepare it fresh. 
 
My thoughts, if you've been to Grubbies, I find this place awfully resembling of it. The cute fish logo reminds me of their fish soy packets and the bowls were kinda similar in style. 

The fish tasted fresh, but immediately entering place  you can smell the fishiness. The pieces of fish are of good size but some pieces were oddly sliced. The fish was good, but something was missing as the texture was non-existent. Salmon was bland, toro was lean, and ebi was skimpy looking. Uni was fine ... but lacked sweetness. Lastly, the rice was too unportional sticky. Fortunately the good thing was the tamago, ikura, and tako. 

+Tamago was sweet and firm
+Ikura was like tiny dragon balls that popped nicely in your mouth
+Tako was tender
++Seaweed pieces were great as it provided extra flavor and texture

I've had better for cheaper. The fact it is located near SF State, I'm sure it'll attract the millenials, me being one of them. 20% discount is a good deal and that's probably the only reason I'll be coming back along with Super Cue right there.

****For another review of this place: My brother Derek L.

excerpts:
They offer around 15 different dons - ranging from the Omakase don to cooked items like Teriyaki Chicken don. 

For three girls, we ordered:
Omakase don - features a range of different sashimi at two to three pieces each: uni, hamachi, tamago, salmon, toro, tuna. 
Rainbow don: another mix of sashimi, very similar to the omakase don
omakase don.author: Miffy Y.
omakase don.review:
I think I found this place through yelp's new businesses and then followed up with looking through pictures of their amazing donburis. Four stars for their creativity and simplicity in opening a place that only serves donburis. Don't expect anything more but don't expect anything less either.

A "don" is short for Donburi which is basically meat and rice in Japanese food language. They offer around 15 different dons - ranging from the Omakase don to cooked items like Teriyaki Chicken don. 

For three girls, we ordered:
Omakase don - features a range of different sashimi at two to three pieces each: uni, hamachi, tamago, salmon, toro, tuna. 
Rainbow don: another mix of sashimi, very similar to the omakase don
Scallop Lover don: scallop sashimi with Ikura 
Unagi don: unagi with sauce over rice

We came in on a Saturday night, 630pm for three, about a 20 min wait. Their fish overall is fresh, better end of Japanese restaurants. They give you enough fish a lot of rice and ikura. We ended up taking the seaweed pieces they gave us to make Ikura nigiris. 

They are still in their soft opening phase. Very apparent with their furnishing and this place is small. Imagine a newly painted apartment living room with open kitchen split in half for you to only dine in the living room portion. Would not recommend a party of more than four. Not cozy at all, pretty bare but comfortable enough for dinner. 

Overall, I would return because I do want to try their Uni special which is only available Tues-Thurs. Otherwise, it would be a go to place for take out donburis! I would not wait more than thirty mins for this place. Just get the take out instead if you have a rainy day.

excerpts: We got the omakase don and rainbow don.
It comes with miso soup and tea gratuit.
The service was friendly and it wasn't difficult to get a seat at 6pm (nor was it hard for anyone who walked in after us to up until 7pm).
For example in the omakase don, no uni is pictured, but you do get uni in your bowl.
A simple difference like that could entirely change my decision if I want a bowl or not!
Granted that they've only been open a month and are still working a few things out, I think they have the potential to build out a strong following of Yelpers and diners soon.
omakase don.author: Joanne Y.
omakase don.review:
Yelp said I might like this place. On Yelp's suggestion, I was feeling a bit whimsical and had a huge craving for sushi so I decided spur of the moment to check this place out. It's kind of far if you live centrally in San Francisco, but it's right off the public transportation line so it's not a terrible trek.

For their soft opening, 20% off was an awesome deal. We got the omakase don and rainbow don. It comes with miso soup and tea gratuit. The service was friendly and it wasn't difficult to get a seat at 6pm (nor was it hard for anyone who walked in after us to up until 7pm). One thing I loved was the amount of fish that you get on top of the chirashi bowl - Kaisen Don is by far one of the more generous places. As for improvements: the rice (as others have mentioned) and quality of wasabi are in need of help. I'm kind of picky about my rice, but I think it could have used more seasoning or "sushi rice flavor". The menu pictures also don't exactly match what you get... For example in the omakase don, no uni is pictured, but you do get uni in your bowl. A simple difference like that could entirely change my decision if I want a bowl or not! Granted that they've only been open a month and are still working a few things out, I think they have the potential to build out a strong following of Yelpers and diners soon. :)

excerpts: For those trying this place for the first time, I suggest going hard and trying their omakase don.
omakase don.author: Eric L.
omakase don.review:
This is one of the hidden new gems on Ocean Ave. Fresh, high quality sashimi for relatively affordable price is a rarity and this place is that.

It's a small place with a small staff so service and wait times reflect that nature. It also smells strongly like the ocean (brininess). 

For those trying this place for the first time, I suggest going hard and trying their omakase don. If you're not a fan of raw fish, their unagi don is made to order and delicious (it can be too much of the same texture/taste for some due to the quantity you're getting). The salmon ochazuke is also a good Asian comfort dish, it's very remeniscent of porridge; something I would order if I was sick. 

All in all, I think this place is worth trying and has become one of my go to places for good sashimi that isn't a Michelin star restaurant. Plus, you can order a goddamn tray of uni here, please.

excerpts: I also got the omakase don and it was well worth it.
It had salmon, tako, tamago, ikura, uni, scallops, hamachi.
Everything was really fresh tasting
and I was pretty content with the dish.
omakase don.author: Jeannie L.
omakase don.review:
I'm definitely a fan. I came here to check out the place since it seemed really promising (and also 20% off during their soft opening is such a good deal). 

I was warned in prior yelp reviews about the fish to rice portion, but I didn't think too much of it. When does anyone not complain about how much rice you get? It did seem like a lot of rice, but I didn't think it was excessive. 

Since it was a weeknight, they had their uni trays and we got the 1/2 tray. It was delicious and creamy. I was pretty happy with the portion as well. At first, it looked like five pieces on five cucumbers with a sprinkle of ikura, but it was about three pieces on top of each other. I also got the omakase don and it was well worth it. It had salmon, tako, tamago, ikura, uni, scallops, hamachi. Everything was really fresh tasting and I was pretty content with the dish. I was pretty stuffed at the end of it. 

Their menu prices changed to be a bit lower. We received three menus with the pricing and then one menu with the changed pricing. I'm sure they are still adjusting in the early stages. The omakase was $28.95 originally but was lowered to $24.95. I thought the prices were pretty reasonable for what you get. 

I'd come back whenever I need a chirashi fix.

excerpts: I had heard so much about Kaisen DON and was so excited to try it!
I was meeting up with friends and we decided to eat here on a whim.
We got here right when it opened.
They informed us that they didn't have any blue Fin tuna at all today
so they would be replacing the bowls with tuna with other fish.
kaisen don.author: Stella J.
kaisen don.review:
I had heard so much about Kaisen DON and was so excited to try it! I was meeting up with friends and we decided to eat here on a whim. We got here right when it opened. They informed us that they didn't have any blue Fin tuna at all today so they would be replacing the bowls with tuna with other fish. The menu is quite extensive in terms of the bowls they have and they have a rotating menu of appetizers and specials! 

I opted for the truffle salmon don and it had 6 pieces of seared salmon topped with truffle sauce. It also came with cucumbers , tamago and some seaweed on the side. The rice was nicely seasoned and when you wrapped the rice, seaweed and salmon together it was delicious! We also tried the salmon ochazuke and it was ok. The salmon was a bit salty but it was still decent. Probably wouldn't be something I order again but I would come back for all the other bowls.

This place is def not on the cheap side, but if you like good quality fish this place is a good option. Can't wait to come back to try the other dons.

Total for 3: $95

excerpts: Kaisen DON defines Chirashi bowls to me.
Came here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was packed.
Every table were seated and I see that every table had at least one Omakase Don-
so I knew I had to order that!
kaisen don.author: Sammi L.
kaisen don.review:
いらっしゃいませ！

Kaisen DON defines Chirashi bowls to me. Came here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was packed. Every table were seated and I see that every table had at least one Omakase Don- so I knew I had to order that! I ordered the Omakase Don along with their daily special: Truffle with Scallops. 

Omakase Don: the bowl have 12 pc of fresh sashimi and sushi rice/ comes with seaweed and wasabi/soy sauce.

Truffle with Scallops: 4 pcs of scallops topped with tobiko and truffle

Overall, the sashimi was fresh but the cut can be more generous. The concept of this place is not bad since they are mainly serving the fresh fish/bowls or hot bowls such as unagi don, salmon ochazuke don, gyu don and etc. If you like chirashi- I recommend coming here! For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.

excerpts: I recently went to Kaisen Don on Ocean Ave for lunch.
They specialize in Chirashi Bowls.
There are 10 Don bowls yet only one vegan option-
Very Green Don- Seaweed, tofu, cucumber, & sweet tofu all over sushi rice.
Kaisen Don is a Rice Bowl which some different Sashimi are placed on Sushi Rice.
kaisen don.author: Shane S.
kaisen don.review:
I recently went to Kaisen Don on Ocean Ave for lunch. They specialize in Chirashi Bowls.  There are 10 Don bowls yet only one vegan option- Very Green Don- Seaweed, tofu, cucumber, & sweet tofu all over sushi rice. This is what I ordered since I am a longtime vegan of 19 years (will get my pension in veganism soon). 

Kaisen Don is a Rice Bowl which some different Sashimi are placed on Sushi Rice. Normally, it's served at Sushi restaurants & is popular for lunch. 

Chirashi, also called chirashizushi (ちらし寿司) is an interesting Japanese meal. The word "chirashi" means "scattered," so this is basically a big bowl of rice mixed with fish, vegetables, & additional ingredients of your choice. Glad they had at least one vegan option. It reminded me of unwrapped sushi in a bowl.

The Very Green Chirashi Don bowl also had pickled ginger & wasabi like is typically accompanied w/ sushi. I found it quite alright yet would love them to have at least one other vegan option such as avocado perhaps or even a more innovative vegan option.

The Very Green Don also came w/ a complimentary miso soup w/ wakame sea vegetables. I had this w/ a side of edamame-seasoned soy beans. 

Although was an interesting experience that I am glad I had would be more likely to return if they had some more interesting vegan options as aforementioned.

excerpts: Kaisen Don is a quaint little family-owned sushi restaurant, bringing you delicious chirashi bowls!
kaisen don.author: Kathy Y.
kaisen don.review:
Kaisen Don is a quaint little family-owned sushi restaurant, bringing you delicious chirashi bowls!
The Omakase Don was amazing; it had fresh & yummy pieces of sashimi, and the sashimi to rice ratio was also perfect! So even though this place is a little more on the pricey side, you get a good amount of the quality sashimi that you're paying for.

excerpts:
We ordered:
Salmon Ikura Don
Kaisen Don
Scallop Lover
All were bomb and fresh!
kaisen don.author: Darlene T.
kaisen don.review:
WOAHHH. BOMB AF. 

I definitely recommend everyone to give this place at try. We ordered:
Salmon Ikura Don
Kaisen Don
Scallop Lover
All were bomb and fresh! I love how they give you a side of seaweed to wrap it like a sushi roll. 

There's not many seats in there. I went on Thursday at opening time 5:30PM and it was not crowded at all. 

Also, check in and get a free edamame, which was actually really good. 

The server was super nice, parking is easy and food was good. Nothing bad to say here. Just go! :) I'm definitely coming back!

excerpts: I have been to Kaisen Don twice since they opened
and I ordered the same thing both times.
Their Omakse Don is pretty good with a wide variety of sashimi.
My personal favorite is their salmon, uni (it can be a hit or miss, the ones I had the first time was so so: however the ones I had the second time was really tasty!) and scallop.
For $34, you get all kinds of fresh seafood, I will definitely go again!
kaisen don.author: Ching L.
kaisen don.review: I have been to Kaisen Don twice since they opened and I ordered the same thing both times. Their Omakse Don is pretty good with a wide variety of sashimi. My personal favorite is their salmon, uni (it can be a hit or miss, the ones I had the first time was so so: however the ones I had the second time was really tasty!) and scallop. For $34, you get all kinds of fresh seafood, I will definitely go again!

excerpts: Kaisen Don is a fantastic little chirashi joint that I have wished into existence.
Kaisen Don is priced fairly for the quality and quantity of food.
kaisen don.author: Tala D.
kaisen don.review:
Updated: Changed my rating from 4 to 5 stars as I've been there a bunch more times since my review and the food is awesome every time. Super consistent and so much fresh uni!!!!

Kaisen Don is a fantastic little chirashi joint that I have wished into existence. Chirashi is my favorite way to eat sushi.

I have been here 3-4 times. Most of the time, I order the Omakase Don and it's always creative and fresh. Last time, in addition to the medley of beautiful seafood atop a perfectly cooked bowl of rice, it came with a small slice of foie gras. Another time, it came with truffled scallops. Always comes with a spot of uni and is so delectable.

The presentation and plating of the sushi here is a clear indication that the chefs in the kitchen know what they're doing and care about their craft. Everything is so artful and pretty, it's hard to dig in!

I wish they sold a simple beer here, such as Sapporo or Orion. I'm guessing they don't have an on-sale beer and wine license.

Kaisen Don is priced fairly for the quality and quantity of food.

Keep up the good work, Kaisen!

excerpts: We order Rainbow Bowl and Kaisen Don, Unagi Don and Sashimi.
The food was delicious and looks nice.
It's a little pricey but good experience to try .
kaisen don.author: Lily L.
kaisen don.review:
We came on a Sunday to eat lunch, it's a small restaurant. The waiter was attentive to our needed and refills our tea.
We order Rainbow Bowl and Kaisen Don, Unagi Don and Sashimi. The food was delicious and looks nice. 
It's a little pricey but good experience to try .

excerpts: but I'm glad I waited on Kaisen Don.
Kaisen Don soft opened about 3 months ago in the former Rainbow T Dessert space.
It's a small restaurant with seating for about 20 people
so it's not a place to come rolling in with your entire posse of 10.
It's ideal for solo diners and couples.
Kaisen Don's specialty is chirashi with about 10 variations.
For those squeamish about raw fish, they have dons with cooked proteins: chicken teriyaki, unagi, chashu, and beef curry.
Each order comes with a complimentary bowl of miso soup.
so I figured it was the perfect time to visit Kaisen Don.
Remember I said, I was glad I waited on visiting Kaisen Don?
Looking at their pictures and their reviews for the past couple of months, it does seem Kaisen Don has some consistency issues and/or still trying to figure things out
but I wouldn't be opposed to returning.
When I'm having a raw craving and don't want to spend $$$ on a nice sushi dinner or deal with the madness at Amami, Kaisen Don will do just fine.
kaisen don.author: Cherylynn N.
kaisen don.review:
New restaurant opening excitement gets the best of some of us. I'm one of the biggest offenders but I'm glad I waited on Kaisen Don.

Kaisen Don soft opened about 3 months ago in the former Rainbow T Dessert space. It's a small restaurant with seating for about 20 people so it's not a place to come rolling in with your entire posse of 10. It's ideal for solo diners and couples. No reservations.   

Kaisen Don's specialty is chirashi with about 10 variations. For those squeamish about raw fish, they have dons with cooked proteins: chicken teriyaki, unagi, chashu, and beef curry. Each order comes with a complimentary bowl of miso soup. Currently, they don't have a liquor license. 

If you see a particular item on their Yelp page that you want, call before visiting. I saw a pic of the shaved ankimo but they didn't have it and the girl at the table in back of me wanted negitoro but they didn't have that either. 

Note to the owner, there's a small discrepancy on your Yelp page. It says, to mention Yelp to get 20% off but the grand opening check-in offer is 10% off. 

Last week, I had some time to kill because of street cleaning in my area so I figured it was the perfect time to visit Kaisen Don.

I ordered the Omakase Don ($28.95): http://bit.ly/2H8jKfF. The fish and seafood toppings will vary daily and based on seasonality. 

On the day, I visited my Omakase don was topped with Mirugai (geoduck), Hamachi (yellowtail), Ikura (salmon roe), Uni (sea urchin), Hotate (scallop), Sake (salmon torched), Amaebi (raw shrimp, no head), Kani w/ its brain (crab leg w/ torched brain), and Tamago (sweet egg omelet). For the value driven folks, the cuts of fish (~12 slices) are thicker than usual for a chirashi. Small sheets of nori are provided so you can make mini hand rolls. 

(+) Good variety with some premium offerings like mirugai and uni. Remember I said, I was glad I waited on visiting Kaisen Don? During their soft opening, the toppings for the omakase don were run-of-the-mill fish like maguro, hamachi, and sake. Didn't see premium offerings. 

(+) Everything was super fresh with my favorite being the perfectly sweet and briny Santa Barbara uni. So good. 

(-) Knife skills could be improved. Several slices didn't have clean edges (i.e. amaebi). 

(-) While the sushi rice was a good temperature and texture, it was underseasoned and plain. 

(-) The wasabi was awful quality (dry, crumbly texture). Yes, it has their cute embossed fish logo but I hope the owner looks into using higher quality wasabi to match their fish.  

Service was polite and friendly. I was their first customer of the day and it took about 20 minutes for my order. 

Minimalist dining area with wooden tables and metal chairs. I enjoyed the 80s and 90s music they were playing. 

Looking at their pictures and their reviews for the past couple of months, it does seem Kaisen Don has some consistency issues and/or still trying to figure things out but I wouldn't be opposed to returning. Their raw fish is good quality and that's what's most important to me.

When I'm having a raw craving and don't want to spend $$$ on a nice sushi dinner or deal with the madness at Amami, Kaisen Don will do just fine.

excerpts: I ordered the Kaisen Don, which had scallops, crab legs, and ikura.
Two of the four scallops that I had in my bowl tasted funny - kind of a stinging/sour feeling in my mouth.
I disregarded it the first time, hoping that the feeling was just from the wasabi, but when I got the same taste after not using any wasabi, I knew it was the scallop.
Either way, I still finished my bowl (big mistake), but I had a pretty intense stomachache after I left.
Luckily, it didn't last the whole night.
kaisen don.author: Cecille W.
kaisen don.review:
I really wanted to love this place but the stomach pain that I had almost immediately after I finished my bowl made me feel otherwise. I ordered the Kaisen Don, which had scallops, crab legs, and ikura. Two of the four scallops that I had in my bowl tasted funny - kind of a stinging/sour feeling in my mouth. I disregarded it the first time, hoping that the feeling was just from the wasabi, but when I got the same taste after not using any wasabi, I knew it was the scallop. Either way, I still finished my bowl (big mistake), but I had a pretty intense stomachache after I left. Luckily, it didn't last the whole night. Maybe I just got unlucky with a few bad pieces of scallop, since, judging from reviews this doesn't happen often. 

On the other hand, my boyfriend ordered the Rainbow Don, which I also tried a bit of. His bowl was great, the fish tasted fresh and we both really liked how they give you strips of seaweed on the side to make your own sushi roll. Every bowl also comes with complimentary miso soup. They also have hot bowls with chasiu or unagi, etc. 

I would say that the chirashi bowls are on the pricer side, around $20-30 per bowl, with the hot bowls a little cheaper. I might be willing to go back to try their other options, but definitely won't be getting any of the scallops!

excerpts: I opted for the Kaisen Don #2 ($18.95) but I wish I had gotten the Scallop Lover ($16.95) instead.
I don't think the crab legs were worth the extra $2 and the scallop was so clean and fresh, the Scallop Lover would have been a better option for me.
Overall, I liked Kaisen Don and the 20% off was definitely a steal.
kaisen don.author: Annie N.
kaisen don.review:
The 20% off your order for their soft opening was definitely a draw in! They didn't specify for how long, but I'd go before it ends!

Their décor was incredibly minimalistic and set a very clean atmosphere. I liked their concept on how to eat the bowls. Not sure if that's the traditional way but I've never seen it before and fell in love. You're supposed to wrap bite sized rolls with the contents of your bowl into the little seaweed pieces that are provided with your dish. I opted for the Kaisen Don #2 ($18.95) but I wish I had gotten the Scallop Lover ($16.95) instead. I don't think the crab legs were worth the extra $2 and the scallop was so clean and fresh, the Scallop Lover would have been a better option for me. 

Overall, I liked Kaisen Don and the 20% off was definitely a steal.

excerpts: so I knew I had to give Kaisen Don a try when I saw it pop up on Yelp!
We were lucky enough to not have to wait at all-
kaisen don.author: Tiffany U.
kaisen don.review:
I'm always in the mood for sashimi so I knew I had to give Kaisen Don a try when I saw it pop up on Yelp! We were lucky enough to not have to wait at all- I could imagine that the wait times will change once people start hearing about this place. 

Here's what I liked:
(+) Fresh sashimi - everything in our omakase don were de-lish especially the crab!
(+) They obviously put thought into the presentation of the donburi so that they are gram ready!
(+) 20% off during their grand opening!
(+) UNI UNI UNI

Here's what I thought could use more work:
(-) The service was not terrible at all, but our waitress was a bit flustered and unorganized.
(-) The 1/2 tray of uni that we ordered didn't really come out in a half tray. It seems to be a smaller portion than what I'm used to, but it could very well be just perception because of the presentation. 

I think I'd definitely come back for more especially while they are still offering 20% off!

excerpts: I ordered the kaisen don #1 and there were a few pieces of tamago, salmon, and ikura.
kaisen don.author: Derek L.
kaisen don.review:
Don't get me wrong, I'm not a sushi hater.  I actually prefer fish over meat because its low in carbs and high in protein.  That equates to less time in the gym to burn off those calories.  

Unfortunately, the portion of rice to fish was excessive.  I would say a majority of the bowl was rice.  I ordered the kaisen don #1 and there were a few pieces of tamago, salmon, and ikura.  Honestly I thought, the omakase don my sister ordered was a better deal.  Especially with the 20% off.  

The yelp says their fish come from the Tsukiji market which is a well known fish trade port in Japan.  However, the preparation of their fish could be improved.  I felt like the texture wasn't firm enough and on the mushier side.  I was also very surprised to find a piece of bone that was still inside one of the yellow tail pieces.  It's fortunate that I didn't swallow the piece whole...

excerpts: I had the Kaisen Don, it was good!
I saw on other yelp posts that there seems to be a Kaisen Don #1 & #2 but the waitress said there's only one Kaisen Don
kaisen don.author: Mandy H.
kaisen don.review:
Decent place with a good concept! Not many places offer a variety of don options. This place has just the right amount! Menu is clean but not overwhelming. 

In terms of value, I've definitely had other chirashi bowls I find more worth it but this place isn't bad at all. Everything was fresh and delicious but portion was a bit small for guys especially.

The complimentary miso soup was very bland. It was like drinking hot water :/ I had the Kaisen Don, it was good! I saw on other yelp posts that there seems to be a Kaisen Don #1 & #2 but the waitress said there's only one Kaisen Don so that was slightly confusing.

I really wanted to try the appetizers (kaisen spoon $7/ea. & scallop burger $10/ea.) but they just seem a bit too pricy for the quantity.

Definitely worth trying but I'm not 100% on coming back because of the price.

excerpts: Kaisen Don is a new donburi restaurant.
They have a wide menu; from curry dons, to unagi dons, and even chirashi dons!
(fresh fish dons).
kaisen don.author: Anthony Y.
kaisen don.review:
A hidden don spot! (Dons are short for donburi which are Japanese rice bowls!)

Kaisen Don is a new donburi restaurant. They have a wide menu; from curry dons, to unagi dons, and even chirashi dons! (fresh fish dons). This looked like a cool new place to try!

My friend and I came at around 7pm on a Monday night. Parking here is atrocious so just a heads up! The restaurant is tiny and most of the tables were filled. Luckily there was some open spaces so my friend and I did not have to wait!

My friend and I both ordered the Rainbow Don (Hamachi (yellow tail), Ikura Roe, Tuna, Salmon, cucumbers, sushi rice, ginger, and wasabi). When you order a don, you get a complimentary miso soup! 

The miso soup was a bit on a salty side for me, but beyond that it was good classic miso soup.
The Rainbow don here is the main attraction for me. First and foremost the presentation of the don cannot be understated. It looked gorgeous and the various colors and textures made it pleasing to the eye. Overall, I liked this dish a lot! The portion size was definitely small, but the quality of the fish and overall ingredients were good. The fishes definitely all had a good amount of fat for me and the taste of each individual fish could be distinguished. However, I definitely think the sushi rice could have been a bit more flavored for me. I didn't realize it was sushi rice until 1/4 of the way in.

Overall while this was an expensive experience it was one to remember. The service here was also very good and friendly, it is something I really appreciated! A lot of the dons are rather expensive, but they have a ton of dons here to try and the rainbow don was definitely something I enjoyed!

excerpts: Kaisen Don is an excellent new Donburi shop near Daly City.
Portions are just the right size for a meal - not too big, not too small and the fish is very fresh.
They're quite small
kaisen don.author: Annie Z.
kaisen don.review:
Kaisen Don is an excellent new Donburi shop near Daly City. Portions are just the right size for a meal - not too big, not too small and the fish is very fresh. They're quite small so seating can be limited, but since the neighborhood is not too busy you shouldn't expect too much of a wait if one at all. 

I like how they put the menu together with basically one concept: chirashi but a variety of different combinations for you to choose from. It's quick, it's easy, and it's yummy.

excerpts: As someone that loves fresh fish and Chirashi style meals, I had really high hopes that Kaisen Don was going to live up to the hype.
kaisen don.author: Diane T.
kaisen don.review:
Came here with the recommendation from a good friend. We showed up around 8pm on a tuesday night and was seated promptly. The restaurant is small, somewhat hidden amongst all the businesses on Ocean Avenue. It's right across the street from 24 hour as a marker. Probably not an ideal location for a big party. 

Overall, we would say that the meal was enjoyable. As someone that loves fresh fish and Chirashi style meals, I had really high hopes that Kaisen Don was going to live up to the hype.

Both the BF and I ordered the Omakase Don which looked beautiful, but for what it was was, I can't say that we were blown away by the quality nor the quantity of the bowl. Like another yelper mentioned, the rice has too much vinegar and the rice to fish ratio was poor. I know quality fresh seafood is pricey, and I expected that, but overall I can't say that the meal was memorable. I've definitely had more enjoyable chirashi dons at other places for better pricing and quality. 

Unfortunately, there was a very strong fish odor when you walk into the restaurant. I know, i know, it's a fresh sushi/sashimi restaurant, of course, it will smell like fish. However, the smell was overwhelming and a bit offputting. 

I believe the best thing we had that night was the scallop truffle burger. It tasted great..but I can't justify the price in the future. 

Would I come back? Probably if i felt like splurging. Would I recommend it to a friend? I'm not sure. Like I said, unfortunately, the meal was not memorable for me. What I do praise is the owner's passion for wanting to bring something he loved from Japan to here. The execution was a good homage to the bowls that we would eat in Japan and it's a great addition to Ocean. 

All in all, it's a local/private business that is worth checking out if you're okay with spending a little more on your meal for seafood.

excerpts: My friend and I wanted to check out Kaisen Don after seeing it on Instragram.
We found seats no problem on a Monday night at 7pm, but the restaurant is tiny, with only room for about 15 people.
kaisen don.author: Jessica L.
kaisen don.review:
Definitely not the best chirashi I've had, but not the worst either.

My friend and I wanted to check out Kaisen Don after seeing it on Instragram.  We found seats no problem on a Monday night at 7pm, but the restaurant is tiny, with only room for about 15 people.  I'd anticipate a wait on the weekend just because of the size of the restaurant.  

They had scallops on special that night, so we went with one omakase don and a scallop don.  I have to say, the scallops were super fresh and sweet.  So good!  The rest of the fish was pretty good too, but I think I was expecting a little more in the omakase after paying $30.  Some other people mentioned this, but what took away from the dishes was the under-seasoned sushi rice and the addition of raw daikon in the don.  Both were bland and I avoided eating the daikon entirely.  It was more like it was put there to take up space in the bowl.  The wasabi was also really low quality, which took away from the taste of the fish.  A lot of what makes a restaurant great is in the details.

Service is really great though, the waitress must have refilled our tea cups 10 times!  I'd be willing to come back if they did something about their wasabi and rice.

Tips and Tricks
-The K line will take you to almost right in front of the restaurant, pretty convenient!
-Almost everything is served as a donburi, not much variety in the menu

excerpts: Order the Kaisen Don & uni special on Tuesday.
the kaisen don again and was truly disappointed.
kaisen don.author: Rio J.
kaisen don.review:
Ok the first 2 times I came I was really happy. Order the Kaisen Don & uni special on Tuesday. Was really happy both times and excited that there was an actually good don place close to my home. 

Unfortunately the 3rd time we came back order the kaisen don again and was truly disappointed. They skimped on the rice, didn't include some of the fish I got the first 2x, fish quality wasn't consistent with the 2 previous visits. 

I'm gonna give it one more try hopefully they redeem themselves because it was really good and convenient.

excerpts: Enough that I wouldn't return and enough that I won't be recommending Kaisen Don.
Rice is extremely important in Japanese cuisine, especially for rice bowls.
The rice here isn't cooked or seasoned the right way.
I understand there's more than one way to season rice, but Kaisen Don's rice isn't authentic.
kaisen don.author: Debbie T.
kaisen don.review:
The fish was fresh. The price and the RICE was not! 

Ugh, the rice was seriously disappointing. Enough that I wouldn't return and enough that I won't be recommending Kaisen Don. Rice is extremely important in Japanese cuisine, especially for rice bowls. The rice here isn't cooked or seasoned the right way. I understand there's more than one way to season rice, but Kaisen Don's rice isn't authentic. Their method for cooking rice and for seasoning rice aren't on par with other Japanese restaurants that fall into the same price point. 

I've been to Japan and other Japanese restaurants located in the nation, and I don't touch rice unless it's good. Hence, it's very disappointing that the only options they have here are rice bowls with disappointing rice.

excerpts: First place I wanted to try coming back home was Kaisen Don.
kaisen don.author: Fiona L.
kaisen don.review:
First place I wanted to try coming back home was Kaisen Don. Thank you Yelp. 

20% off Chirashi bowls? YES.
This means that the most bang for your buck is to order the most expensive one. And that's what I did. I got the Omakase Don $28.95 which included Tako, Hamachi, Salmon, Ikura, Tuna, Ebi, AND Uni. The Uni wasn't specified in the menu or picture, but I got it anyways. Merry Christmas to me! 

The restaurant is small and limited to small parties. The menu is simple as it comes with different kinds of dons (donburis). Although not stated in the menu, it comes with a bowl of mushroom miso soup which was a delightful start to the meal. 

The bowl takes quite a while to make as I'm sure they prepare it fresh. 
 
My thoughts, if you've been to Grubbies, I find this place awfully resembling of it. The cute fish logo reminds me of their fish soy packets and the bowls were kinda similar in style. 

The fish tasted fresh, but immediately entering place  you can smell the fishiness. The pieces of fish are of good size but some pieces were oddly sliced. The fish was good, but something was missing as the texture was non-existent. Salmon was bland, toro was lean, and ebi was skimpy looking. Uni was fine ... but lacked sweetness. Lastly, the rice was too unportional sticky. Fortunately the good thing was the tamago, ikura, and tako. 

+Tamago was sweet and firm
+Ikura was like tiny dragon balls that popped nicely in your mouth
+Tako was tender
++Seaweed pieces were great as it provided extra flavor and texture

I've had better for cheaper. The fact it is located near SF State, I'm sure it'll attract the millenials, me being one of them. 20% discount is a good deal and that's probably the only reason I'll be coming back along with Super Cue right there.

****For another review of this place: My brother Derek L.

excerpts: We got the Kaisen Don #1 and the Rainbow Don.
We waited a bit for our food to come out, but it wasn't too bad.
And, we had some miso soup to sip on while we waited.
I was pleasantly surprised when we got our food.
The bowls were so beautiful, especially the Kaisen Don!
Each piece of fish seemed meticulously place.
kaisen don.author: Christine L.
kaisen don.review:
I've had good experiences with Chirashi bowls, and I was excited to try this place since it's close by and there aren't many places like it in the neighborhood. 

The place was cute! I liked the hip wooden decor and minimalistic branding. It is small, but we got there before noon, so there was still lots of seating. 

We got the Kaisen Don #1 and the Rainbow Don. We waited a bit for our food to come out, but it wasn't too bad. And, we had some miso soup to sip on while we waited. I was pleasantly surprised when we got our food. The bowls were so beautiful, especially the Kaisen Don!  Each piece of fish seemed meticulously place. I loved the little wasabi stamped with the store logo. 

They give you really crisp seaweed on the side to go with your bowl. I liked how the wasabi on the milder side, not as nose-tingling as other places,. The fish and shrimp was very fresh, not fishy at all. And it was a fair amount of fish for what we paid for. The flavor of the sushi rice was good, not overpowering, and the texture was nice and sticky. The amount of rice was typical for a Chirashi bowl. I wasn't a huge fan of the tamago as it was too sweet for me. I typically like it saltier, but it was nice and firm. It was a good amount of food for me, so I was pretty full by the end of the meal. 

The owner was very nice and came by to refill our cups whenever we ran out of tea. 

Overall, it was a great experience, and I would definitely come back again. They mentioned they would be adding more stuff to the menu in January! I'm excited to try the new stuff!

excerpts: They give a very nice portion in the Rainbow Bowl and the Kaisen don.
All the sashimi is very fresh.
This place is surprisingly not crowded considering how small it is, but maybe its the location.
Overall, fair price for quality sashimi bowl.
kaisen don.author: Nikita K.
kaisen don.review: A fun casual chirashi spot! They give a very nice portion in the Rainbow Bowl and the Kaisen don. All the sashimi is very fresh. This place is surprisingly not crowded considering how small it is, but maybe its the location. Overall, fair price for quality sashimi bowl.

excerpts: One thing I loved was the amount of fish that you get on top of the chirashi bowl - Kaisen Don is by far one of the more generous places.
As for improvements: the rice (as others have mentioned) and quality of wasabi are in need of help.
I'm kind of picky about my rice, but I think it could have used more seasoning or "sushi rice flavor".
The menu pictures also don't exactly match what you get...
kaisen don.author: Joanne Y.
kaisen don.review:
Yelp said I might like this place. On Yelp's suggestion, I was feeling a bit whimsical and had a huge craving for sushi so I decided spur of the moment to check this place out. It's kind of far if you live centrally in San Francisco, but it's right off the public transportation line so it's not a terrible trek.

For their soft opening, 20% off was an awesome deal. We got the omakase don and rainbow don. It comes with miso soup and tea gratuit. The service was friendly and it wasn't difficult to get a seat at 6pm (nor was it hard for anyone who walked in after us to up until 7pm). One thing I loved was the amount of fish that you get on top of the chirashi bowl - Kaisen Don is by far one of the more generous places. As for improvements: the rice (as others have mentioned) and quality of wasabi are in need of help. I'm kind of picky about my rice, but I think it could have used more seasoning or "sushi rice flavor". The menu pictures also don't exactly match what you get... For example in the omakase don, no uni is pictured, but you do get uni in your bowl. A simple difference like that could entirely change my decision if I want a bowl or not! Granted that they've only been open a month and are still working a few things out, I think they have the potential to build out a strong following of Yelpers and diners soon. :)

excerpts: This restaurant specializes in Kaisen don's (hence the name of the restaurant).
Kaisen dons are basically rice bowls with different types of sashimi on top.
kaisen don.author: Eunice C.
kaisen don.review: This was such an unexpected find! So glad that my sisters and I decided to try this place. This restaurant specializes in Kaisen don's (hence the name of the restaurant). Kaisen dons are basically rice bowls with different types of sashimi on top. I got the rainbow don, but I switched out the tuna for more salmon sashimi. The quality of the fish was top notch! I could tell the fish was super clean and fresh. There wasn't any fishy smell or taste at all. Would definitely recommend trying out this hidden gem!

excerpts: We definitely fall in love with Kaisen Don and it is very close to our place.
Can't wait again for this coming Monday!
kaisen don.author: Salie E.
kaisen don.review: A very small restaurant but has a marvelous japanese sushi and Donburi meals to offer. We went here on Mondays because we always go for the oysters happy hour which means $1 per oyster.  We definitely fall in love with Kaisen Don and it is very close to our place. Can't wait again for this coming Monday!

excerpts: Kaisen Don！
kaisen don.author: Yuri Z.
kaisen don.review: the best ikura I have in US！Sweet and umami！very nice service！five stars for this place. I will come back again even Im in east coast！flight straight for Kaisen Don！

excerpts: Kaisen Don is a great addition to Ocean Ave.
The Don menu is divided logically between sashimi and non-sashimi selections.
They have high-end delicacies and staple items on the menu.
kaisen don.author: R S.
kaisen don.review:
Kaisen Don is a great addition to Ocean Ave. The Don menu is divided logically between sashimi and non-sashimi selections. They have high-end delicacies and staple items on the menu. The uni and scallop specials are incredible and make their way into the don dishes. 

Street parking is not difficult. Small venue, great for lunch and dinner. 

Aviento 5 estrellas. Buen provecho!

excerpts: Got the Kaisen Don and the daily special of the uni and hotate don.
The scallop and ikura was decently fresh.
The rice was a disappointment, mushy and bland.
Added ebi, so not worth it, $5 for a tiny piece of shrimp.
Total after tax for 2 don plus the ebi was $43.
Each don came with a bowl of watery miso soup.
Went on a Saturday and it was not buzzing, plenty of parking too.
Come to get your don fix, but don't expect too much.
kaisen don.author: Erica B.
kaisen don.review: A-ok. Got the Kaisen Don and the daily special of the uni and hotate don. The scallop and ikura was decently fresh. The rice was a disappointment, mushy and bland. Added ebi, so not worth it, $5 for a tiny piece of shrimp. Total after tax for 2 don plus the ebi was $43. Each don came with a bowl of watery miso soup. Went on a Saturday and it was not buzzing, plenty of parking too. Come to get your don fix, but don't expect too much.

excerpts: I ordered the Kaisen Don #1, but at full price, I would not.
Its about $19 for the bowl.
At that price, I'm expecting an extra slice of salmon or 2 and one more sweet shrimp.
kaisen don.author: Chris C.
kaisen don.review:
This is more of a 1.5 star review. Anyone with a 3+ star review has either:
-never had a decent chirashi bowl
-has a diet consisting of Old Town chirashi (see above)
-was high while eating

Why?

I know its 20% off, but is it also 20% off the portions as well? I ordered the Kaisen Don #1, but at full price, I would not. Its about $19 for the bowl. At that price, I'm expecting an extra slice of salmon or 2 and one more sweet shrimp. Also leave the lemon out, it just doesn't go with the bowl.

As for the taste, its alright, but not worth $19-alright. The rice was plain, where's the seasoning/rice vinegar? Hello? I mean it's just rice but the rice vinegar makes a big difference especially when paired with raw fish. 

Also, get rid of the lemon, the lemon rubs onto the fish and partially masks the freshness the taste/freshness of the fish. Unless you're using shitty fish, get rid of the shitty lemon. Once you use rice vinegar, the lemon will be too overbearing anyways. Or put it to the side if you insist putting lemon in the bowl.

Another, the thickness of the cut of the fish. The salmon were basically in blocks in my don (there's much photographic proof that this is so on this yelp page). Just look at the photos, they're goddamn 2-match-box-combined sized chunks.
The reason why a lot of chirashi places have thinner slices is so people can easily wrap their fish around their rice and dip it in sauce. But instead, you have a block of salmon which you eat separately from the rice. 

The radish. 
The goddamn pile of #radish.
Sure it makes it instagrammable or whatever, but nobody eats that much radish with chirashi. If you insist on leaving that much radish then at least place it over a leaf/seaweed/lettuce so people can pull out all the radish in one fell swoop instead of picking at it to remove it.

Just from these small but important details you can tell these guys were just like "Oh hey let's just open a Chirashi place because it's easy to make the food and it's popular" without much regard on how Chirashi is supposed to be made.

One more thing to pick at: "bringing Tsukiji's food CULTURE". So is the fish from Tsukiji or are you guys only talking about the food culture in which they have fresh fish everyday? Because this place is literally just fish over rice and not how chirashi actually is.

I think this place can be a lot better. I think SF needs more chirashi places like this one BUT BETTER. I hope my review has given you some insight what to expect (as a potential customer) and what can be improved (as the owner). I'm hoping when I give this place a 2nd chance in a month or so, it'll become a place I can bring my friends without feeling embarrassed.

excerpts: * Wide selection of bowls - if you aren't into fresh fish, you should go somewhere else, this is Kaisen Don meaning "sashimi fish on rice"!
If they were a true Kaisen Don as their name suggests, then this would be true.
However they do offer beef, salmon or beef curry on rice among other things.

* Friendly owner
*
kaisen don.author: Mark M.
kaisen don.review:
Pluses are:
* Super fresh fish - plus the ikura was glistening and popped in your mouth! Also, slices are good sized (1/4" thick). 
* Wide selection of bowls - if you aren't into fresh fish, you should go somewhere else, this is Kaisen Don meaning "sashimi fish on rice"! If they were a true Kaisen Don as their name suggests, then this would be true. However they do offer beef, salmon or beef curry on rice among other things.
* Friendly owner
* Continued 20% off discount after soft opening

Cons:
* Weird/small table layout - I realize they are still working things out, but after 1 month they need to get this squared. Waiting families had no where to sit, but stand against the wall?!? When we were there, the layout was a definite fire hazard and non-handicapped compliant.
* Unusually long wait time - we had to wait about 25 minutes after ordering to get our bowls. Fish put on rice. That is essentially what the bowls are. Felt awkward when people waiting for a table are almost right in your face.
* Cost - borderline high. The 20% discount helped, but I think that people should take photos with some reference in it like a phone or something. *I shouldn't talk as I didn't do it either.* In the photos the bowls "seem" big and packed with goodies. Again, the fish is super fresh. But we actually left a little hungry.

Lastly, I hope that this restaurant tries to understand the minute differences that true Japanese restaurants reflect. A huge plus they already have is the quality of fish. However, omakase means to "let the chef decide". It does not mean "put a little of each thing on the menu". "Omakase" is meant for the best of the best that day, so what it includes will also change day to day. As a Japanese customer, it saddened me.

excerpts: I don't 100% remember what she ordered but I believe it was the Kaisen Don #1
It honestly had me craving some Poki Time at Westlake just because the fish portion at Kaisen Don just wasn't enough.
I'm hoping that Kaisen Don can turn it around though.
They have a great product but the prices are just too steep.
I wish them the best!
kaisen don.author: R C.
kaisen don.review:
Picked up some dinner here a couple weeks ago. Small place with a couple of tables, probably seats around 15 people. The inside is nice and clean albeit a little plain. I ordered takeout for my girlfriend and I though since it was a cold night and I wanted to get home quickly to watch the Warriors game. The guy who took our takeout order was nice and gave us ample time to pick what we wanted.

I don't 100% remember what she ordered but I believe it was the Kaisen Don #1 and I ordered the Rainbow Don. The fish was very fresh but unfortunately, the portions don't match the price. My girlfriend gets full pretty easily but she ended up still being slightly hungry. Personally, I think I might have needed two to fill me up. It's about 3 pieces of each fish in the don. I know in order for them to have premium fish quality, they have to charge higher than other places but the prices are still too high. For this specific order, I still ended up spending around $30, even with the 20% discount they offered. I don't think I could fathom the thought of coming here without that discount. It honestly had me craving some Poki Time at Westlake just because the fish portion at Kaisen Don just wasn't enough.

I'm hoping that Kaisen Don can turn it around though. They have a great product but the prices are just too steep. I wish them the best!

excerpts: We ordered a Kaisen Don #1, Hamachi don and a rainbow don.
Fish were fresh and nice portion.
I like how they serve the seaweed on a side and I can assemble my own sushi roll.
I will definitely come back again to try other don!
kaisen don.author: Vic L.
kaisen don.review: Very impressed with the quality of the fish! We ordered a Kaisen Don #1, Hamachi don and a rainbow don. Fish were fresh and nice portion. I like how they serve the seaweed on a side and I can assemble my own sushi roll. I will definitely come back again to try other don!

excerpts: Kaisen Don has good Donburi.
The  fish  is fresh and the rice is good.
We went on a weekday and it wasn't crowded.
The staff is also very friendly and took their time explaining the menu.
A little pricey, but worth it for fresh seafood.
kaisen don.author: Wilson W.
kaisen don.review: Kaisen Don has good Donburi. The  fish  is fresh and the rice is good. We went on a weekday and it wasn't crowded. The staff is also very friendly and took their time explaining the menu. A little pricey, but worth it for fresh seafood.

excerpts: Here's another review hoping that Kaisen Don steps up it's rice game.
The rice at Kaisen Don was close to a good texture but slightly too wet and mushy, and completely lacked in any flavor whatsoever.
kaisen don.author: Mack S.
kaisen don.review:
Here's another review hoping that Kaisen Don steps up it's rice game. 

It's unfortunate that with most sushi restaurants, rice is an afterthought and the fish is main attraction when it should be entirely the other way around. The rice at Kaisen Don was close to a good texture but slightly too wet and mushy, and completely lacked in any flavor whatsoever. No signs of sushi-su or sweetness and it ended up completely bland, reminding me of plain white porridge, which is really unfortunate because this place seems promising.
