The fish, while not the best, was portioned very reasonably for the price. The nori provided was the highlight for me, I only wish that they provided a small dish to put them somewhere. I had to place them awkwardly on top of my don bowl as I ate, and ended up moving them onto my napkin.

Overall, I'm looking forward to giving this place another try in the future.

excerpts: I enjoyed every bite of my Kaisen Don.
kaisen don.author: Dennis L.
kaisen don.review:
Small place, but my good friend recommended me.  I love Japanese food, sushi, sashimi, ramen, udon.. all my favorites.  I even have an Japanese cuisine expert showing me the good stuff in SF and elsewhere in the world.  I don't claim to be "the expert", but I certainly do enjoy food.  When I go to Japanese restaurants, I do scan the menu for chirashi bowls.  I love sushi rice and sashimi.  You can pair the right of rice with your fish, and I pick my favorite flavor of fish.  When I heard that there's a new place that specializes Chirashi, I was super excited.  

At a glance, the place is small, looks modern, somewhat resembles bubble tea/fast food restaurant.  Dinning room seats small amount of guests, this is probably due to SF regulations.  Things looks very clean and sterile.  When I walked it, around 5:40pm, it wasn't so busy, but I realized there was a line outside the door about 15 minutes after i sat down.  

I was brought a menu with very nice pictures.  Not too much choices as a regular Japanese restaurant, but enough choices.  There are the scallop lover, Hamachi love, blue blue fin tuna, and even uni or toro.  The prices to me compare to many Japanese restaurants' Chirashi bowls are rather reasonable.  Usually, the Chirashi in a regular Japanese place is about 25 bucks above.  You can get the same less than 20 plus a 20% yelp discount - that is a deal.

I brought my family there, my wife and two kids.  We ordered a box of uni for appetizer.  My wife ordered the Rainbow bowl, and I ordered the hamachi bowl.  I ordered the thin slice beef bowl for my kids to share.  The bowls came up rather quickly, but not all at once.  They were well presented.  The chef did really take a lot of time making sure the bowls presentable.  The fish are very fresh and high quality.  I enjoyed every bite of my Kaisen Don.  

While I was there, I was able to located the owner, Larry.  While the places wasn't too busy, he told me about where he learned how to make chirashi bowls.  He basically like me who love chirashi.  He also recommended me to mix and match your chirashi bowls, and don't have to pick from the menu.

I did read Chris' review, and I appreciate him pointing out how Larry's chirashi isn't the perfect chirashi for him.  Perhaps Larry can learn something from his review.  For me, I am pretty satisfy with mine, or Larry's representation.  I feel that if everyone's chirashi is exactly the same, there won't be any innovation in food.  We will eat the same thing for hundreds of years, but perhaps someone like Chris will enjoy that, and there is nothing wrong with that.  Larry is certainly someone who will probably take advice from his toughest critics.  If not, how else would you make your customers happy.  5 stars for my experience.  Thank you Larry.

excerpts: The toro don was made with chopped up fatty tuna under ikura.
Not sure I liked the chopped up toro with the rice by itself, but wrapped in the seaweed was like a negi toro handroll which was great (LOVE negi toro).
They gave us about 3-4 pieces of seaweed which wasn't enough
so we had to keep asking for more seaweed and that was an additional cost.
We also ordered a side order of scallop sashimi which was also fresh.
Overall, a very yummy meal but not completely filling.
And for $20-30 for a bowl was pretty fricken pricey for the portion plus the additional costs for the seaweed is crazy.
Haven't made a trip back since then
but I noticed they offer more now and even have nigiri's.
toro don.author: Anissa D.
toro don.review: Pricey but yum. Came here a while back. like a while back, but never wrote a review. Tried their Rainbow Don ($18.95) and NegiToro Don ($35.95). The rainbow don came with 3 pieces of hamachi, tuna, salmon, and cucumber over a bowl of rice. Sashimi was fresh and nicely sliced. The toro don was made with chopped up fatty tuna under ikura. Not sure I liked the chopped up toro with the rice by itself, but wrapped in the seaweed was like a negi toro handroll which was great (LOVE negi toro). They gave us about 3-4 pieces of seaweed which wasn't enough so we had to keep asking for more seaweed and that was an additional cost. We also ordered a side order of scallop sashimi which was also fresh. Overall, a very yummy meal but not completely filling. And for $20-30 for a bowl was pretty fricken pricey for the portion plus the additional costs for the seaweed is crazy. Haven't made a trip back since then but I noticed they offer more now and even have nigiri's.

excerpts:
We ordered:
Salmon Ikura Don
Kaisen Don
Scallop Lover
All were bomb and fresh!
scallop lover.author: Darlene T.
scallop lover.review:
WOAHHH. BOMB AF. 

I definitely recommend everyone to give this place at try. We ordered:
Salmon Ikura Don
Kaisen Don
Scallop Lover
All were bomb and fresh! I love how they give you a side of seaweed to wrap it like a sushi roll. 

There's not many seats in there. I went on Thursday at opening time 5:30PM and it was not crowded at all. 

Also, check in and get a free edamame, which was actually really good. 

The server was super nice, parking is easy and food was good. Nothing bad to say here. Just go! :) I'm definitely coming back!

excerpts: I opted for the Kaisen Don #2 ($18.95) but I wish I had gotten the Scallop Lover ($16.95) instead.
I don't think the crab legs were worth the extra $2 and the scallop was so clean and fresh, the Scallop Lover would have been a better option for me.
Overall, I liked Kaisen Don and the 20% off was definitely a steal.
scallop lover.author: Annie N.
scallop lover.review:
The 20% off your order for their soft opening was definitely a draw in! They didn't specify for how long, but I'd go before it ends!

Their décor was incredibly minimalistic and set a very clean atmosphere. I liked their concept on how to eat the bowls. Not sure if that's the traditional way but I've never seen it before and fell in love. You're supposed to wrap bite sized rolls with the contents of your bowl into the little seaweed pieces that are provided with your dish. I opted for the Kaisen Don #2 ($18.95) but I wish I had gotten the Scallop Lover ($16.95) instead. I don't think the crab legs were worth the extra $2 and the scallop was so clean and fresh, the Scallop Lover would have been a better option for me. 

Overall, I liked Kaisen Don and the 20% off was definitely a steal.

excerpts:
Scallop Lover don: scallop sashimi with Ikura 
Unagi don: unagi with sauce over rice
scallop lover.author: Miffy Y.
scallop lover.review:
I think I found this place through yelp's new businesses and then followed up with looking through pictures of their amazing donburis. Four stars for their creativity and simplicity in opening a place that only serves donburis. Don't expect anything more but don't expect anything less either.

A "don" is short for Donburi which is basically meat and rice in Japanese food language. They offer around 15 different dons - ranging from the Omakase don to cooked items like Teriyaki Chicken don. 

For three girls, we ordered:
Omakase don - features a range of different sashimi at two to three pieces each: uni, hamachi, tamago, salmon, toro, tuna. 
Rainbow don: another mix of sashimi, very similar to the omakase don
Scallop Lover don: scallop sashimi with Ikura 
Unagi don: unagi with sauce over rice

We came in on a Saturday night, 630pm for three, about a 20 min wait. Their fish overall is fresh, better end of Japanese restaurants. They give you enough fish a lot of rice and ikura. We ended up taking the seaweed pieces they gave us to make Ikura nigiris. 

They are still in their soft opening phase. Very apparent with their furnishing and this place is small. Imagine a newly painted apartment living room with open kitchen split in half for you to only dine in the living room portion. Would not recommend a party of more than four. Not cozy at all, pretty bare but comfortable enough for dinner. 

Overall, I would return because I do want to try their Uni special which is only available Tues-Thurs. Otherwise, it would be a go to place for take out donburis! I would not wait more than thirty mins for this place. Just get the take out instead if you have a rainy day.

The prices to me compare to many Japanese restaurants' Chirashi bowls are rather reasonable.
Usually, the Chirashi in a regular Japanese place is about 25 bucks above.

excerpts: We ordered scallop lover and rainbow don.
scallop lover.author: Michelle T.
scallop lover.review:
The wait for Saturday lunch was short, about 5 mins. We ordered scallop lover and rainbow don. Food came with hot tea and hot miso soup (yums). 

Both dons came with a good amount of warm sushi rice. The presentation was beautiful (should've taken pictures but too hungry!) The fish and scallops were really fresh! No fishy taste or random chewy bits. The hot tea kept flowing throughout the meal. No complaints. 

For non raw fish eaters, they have a selection of cooked dons which looked equally as impressive.

excerpts: We usually get the rainbow don, tuna don, chirashi and gyu-don.
tuna don.author: Joy S.
tuna don.review: Love this place! This is our go to Japanese place. We did noticed that the portions have gotten smaller which bums me out. We usually get the rainbow don, tuna don, chirashi and gyu-don.

excerpts: We ordered a few items: Omakase Don, Hamachi Don and Blue Fin Tuna.
Food looked good and tasted fresh for the most part.
hamachi don.author: Roman L.
hamachi don.review:
We came to this place to see what people have been talking about. We ordered a few items: Omakase Don, Hamachi Don and Blue Fin Tuna. Food looked good and tasted fresh for the most part. Our stomachs weren't happy afterwards so doubt that we will be coming back anytime soon. 

Pros:
Food presentation can look good on instagram.

Cons:
Way too much rice.
Not worth the price point.
Service can be improved. (It's extremely awkward and rude for them to stand over your shoulder as you try to figure out how much tip you want to leave!)

This was our personal experience and thoughts, though others may feel different. All in all, we won't be rushing back anytime soon and probably won't be recommending to friends or family.

excerpts: Hamachi Don
hamachi don.author: Belinda C.
hamachi don.review:
So I've been coming here for months and i've been behind on reviews.  When they first started the prices were reasonable, but now they are slightly higher.  Most of that time that will matter, but the food is honestly really fresh.  I love how they have a daily special menu and it changes everyday.  Which is kinda a hit or a miss.   One of the times i came here i had the salmon truffle don and was so amazing.  It was rich and fresh at the same time and once you've tried this, you'll get addicted to it.  Our at least i got addicted to it.  I also had the scallop burger which was sandwich between the seaweed with uni.  It was so delicious!! I wish i can order more of this!  There are days they have uni specials where you can order a half or full plate of uni, but watch your wallet. 

Here's are the types of Dons i had in the order i like it

Salmon truffle Don
Scallop Lover Don
Rainbow Don
Hamachi Don

I wish parking was here at night, but i guess if it was easier, i'll come her a little too much.  All the times i've been here, the service was always perfect.  I recommend this place to any lovers of chirishi or sashimi.

excerpts: I prefer to get the Hamachi Don ($16.95) which is smaller
hamachi don.author: Kathleen N.
hamachi don.review:
Delish and legit dons!

You are definitely tasting quality with every bite of fresh sashimi, sweet roe, and perfectly cooked sushi rice. 

The pricing is a bit steep, but you do get what you pay for! Omakase Don was $29 which has a variety of everything, including uni. I personally thought it was way too much food. I prefer to get the Hamachi Don ($16.95) which is smaller but oh-so delicious with healthy slices of hamachi and topped with a quarter bowl of sweet roe. 

I also tried the Scallop Burger ($9.99) which consisted of two pieces of scallops sandwiching uni and truffle butter. This was decent but wouldn't get again. 

The restaurant is pretty small with only 5 tables or so. I wouldn't bring a huge group as there is only one "big" table that can fit up to 6 people.

excerpts: We ordered a Kaisen Don #1, Hamachi don and a rainbow don.
Fish were fresh and nice portion.
I like how they serve the seaweed on a side and I can assemble my own sushi roll.
I will definitely come back again to try other don!
hamachi don.author: Vic L.
hamachi don.review: Very impressed with the quality of the fish! We ordered a Kaisen Don #1, Hamachi don and a rainbow don. Fish were fresh and nice portion. I like how they serve the seaweed on a side and I can assemble my own sushi roll. I will definitely come back again to try other don!

excerpts: I ordered the rainbow don, which came with hamachi, salmon, and tuna.
The sashimi were fresh and thick.
I also got the uni sampler, which came with uni from Peru (Peru produce uni??), Mexico, and Santa Barbara, 3 pierces each.
rainbow don.author: Angela T.
rainbow don.review:
This place specializes in Chirashi bowls. I ordered the rainbow don, which came with hamachi, salmon, and tuna. The sashimi were fresh and thick. I also got the uni sampler, which came with uni from Peru (Peru produce uni??), Mexico, and Santa Barbara, 3 pierces each. SB uni won the crown. 

The waitress was extra nice to us!! 5 star service!

excerpts: their standard menu.i tried the rainbow don and the eel don.
rainbow don.author: Bonnie C.
rainbow don.review:
A unique dinning experience. The place is small but the staff are nice. They have one menu for specials of the day and their standard menu.i tried the rainbow don and the eel don.

The eel was war and flavorful. I wish it had more sauce tho. The miso soup was nice and not salty Iike most places I have tried. The rainbow don't comes with 3 slices of salmon, 3 slices of tuna and 3 blue tail fish. I have never tried the blue tail fish, but it was fresh and nice. 

The basic concept of the place I believe is like finger food and you can make your own hand roll. I wish it had more fish, because you get more seaweed to fish, or maybe I'm suppose to cut the fish in half to make a better hand roll. But will come back to try another dish. It does get busy after 6:30.

excerpts: My main was the rainbow don and the SO got the omakase don.
Both of our dons tasted very fishy and overall we felt that the fish was not very fresh.
rainbow don.author: Andrea K.
rainbow don.review:
The SO and I are absolute sushi lovers and were disappointed with our experience. The service was alright-- it was sometimes difficult to flag down a waiter/waitress as the two people working that night were chatting by the registers. 

We started with a scallop burger and blue fin sashimi. The uni in the scallop burger had a funky flavor that completely overpowered the scallops and the blue fin was very fishy and not melt-in-your-mouth tender. My main was the rainbow don and the SO got the omakase don. Both of our dons tasted very fishy and overall we felt that the fish was not very fresh. There was a decent fish to rice proportion but I ended up eating a lot of the rice to cover up the fishy flavor. 

I'm hoping that my one experience was just an off day and I'd like to try it out again in the future... but it's just a bit on the pricier end for sushi.

excerpts: My friend and I both decided on the Rainbow Don, which cane with salmon, hamachi, and tuna.
They didn't have tuna that day, so I subbed for scallops.
The portions were decent, and the sashimi slices were fatty.
It came with seaweed strips, which ended up being a good idea with the sashimi and rice.
Of the three sashimi choices, my favorite was the salmon.
rainbow don.author: Sandra S.
rainbow don.review:
This place is pretty good if you're looking to satisfy your craving for sashimi and sushi! We came at around 7pm on a Saturday night and there was a small wait. The parking wasn't too bad, but it was all street parking. 

My friend and I both decided on the Rainbow Don, which cane with salmon, hamachi, and tuna. They didn't have tuna that day, so I subbed for scallops. The portions were decent, and the sashimi slices were fatty. It came with seaweed strips, which ended up being a good idea with the sashimi and rice. Of the three sashimi choices, my favorite was the salmon. The scallop has somewhat of an unusual taste, and they weren't sweet and fresh like they usually should taste. 

Prices are a little high for the chirachi here but nonetheless, a pretty good experience overall!

excerpts: Rainbow Don
rainbow don.author: Belinda C.
rainbow don.review:
So I've been coming here for months and i've been behind on reviews.  When they first started the prices were reasonable, but now they are slightly higher.  Most of that time that will matter, but the food is honestly really fresh.  I love how they have a daily special menu and it changes everyday.  Which is kinda a hit or a miss.   One of the times i came here i had the salmon truffle don and was so amazing.  It was rich and fresh at the same time and once you've tried this, you'll get addicted to it.  Our at least i got addicted to it.  I also had the scallop burger which was sandwich between the seaweed with uni.  It was so delicious!! I wish i can order more of this!  There are days they have uni specials where you can order a half or full plate of uni, but watch your wallet. 

Here's are the types of Dons i had in the order i like it

Salmon truffle Don
Scallop Lover Don
Rainbow Don
Hamachi Don

I wish parking was here at night, but i guess if it was easier, i'll come her a little too much.  All the times i've been here, the service was always perfect.  I recommend this place to any lovers of chirishi or sashimi.

excerpts: Tried their Rainbow Don ($18.95) and NegiToro Don ($35.95).
The rainbow don came with 3 pieces of hamachi, tuna, salmon, and cucumber over a bowl of rice.
Sashimi was fresh and nicely sliced.
rainbow don.author: Anissa D.
rainbow don.review: Pricey but yum. Came here a while back. like a while back, but never wrote a review. Tried their Rainbow Don ($18.95) and NegiToro Don ($35.95). The rainbow don came with 3 pieces of hamachi, tuna, salmon, and cucumber over a bowl of rice. Sashimi was fresh and nicely sliced. The toro don was made with chopped up fatty tuna under ikura. Not sure I liked the chopped up toro with the rice by itself, but wrapped in the seaweed was like a negi toro handroll which was great (LOVE negi toro). They gave us about 3-4 pieces of seaweed which wasn't enough so we had to keep asking for more seaweed and that was an additional cost. We also ordered a side order of scallop sashimi which was also fresh. Overall, a very yummy meal but not completely filling. And for $20-30 for a bowl was pretty fricken pricey for the portion plus the additional costs for the seaweed is crazy. Haven't made a trip back since then but I noticed they offer more now and even have nigiri's.

excerpts: We ordered the omakase don, the rainbow don, and the kaisen spoon.
All were completely delicious.
The omakase don had a good variety of fish and a great rice ratio.
Super fresh and tasty.
Same with the rainbow don.
rainbow don.author: Yanni L.
rainbow don.review:
This place is delicious and full of noms! We ordered the omakase don, the rainbow don, and the kaisen spoon. All were completely delicious. The omakase don had a good variety of fish and a great rice ratio. Super fresh and tasty. Same with the rainbow don. The kaisen spoon (which I believe has oyster, ikura, tobiko, and ponzu sauce) was really flavorful and a perfect portion size.

Service was great and the complimentary tea was surprisingly tasty. The complimentary edamame (check-in with Yelp) was decent and nothing special but nice for a small, free appetizer. 

Can't wait to go back!

excerpts: On the other hand, my boyfriend ordered the Rainbow Don, which I also tried a bit of.
His bowl was great, the fish tasted fresh and we both really liked how they give you strips of seaweed on the side to make your own sushi roll.
Every bowl also comes with complimentary miso soup.
rainbow don.author: Cecille W.
rainbow don.review:
I really wanted to love this place but the stomach pain that I had almost immediately after I finished my bowl made me feel otherwise. I ordered the Kaisen Don, which had scallops, crab legs, and ikura. Two of the four scallops that I had in my bowl tasted funny - kind of a stinging/sour feeling in my mouth. I disregarded it the first time, hoping that the feeling was just from the wasabi, but when I got the same taste after not using any wasabi, I knew it was the scallop. Either way, I still finished my bowl (big mistake), but I had a pretty intense stomachache after I left. Luckily, it didn't last the whole night. Maybe I just got unlucky with a few bad pieces of scallop, since, judging from reviews this doesn't happen often. 

On the other hand, my boyfriend ordered the Rainbow Don, which I also tried a bit of. His bowl was great, the fish tasted fresh and we both really liked how they give you strips of seaweed on the side to make your own sushi roll. Every bowl also comes with complimentary miso soup. They also have hot bowls with chasiu or unagi, etc. 

I would say that the chirashi bowls are on the pricer side, around $20-30 per bowl, with the hot bowls a little cheaper. I might be willing to go back to try their other options, but definitely won't be getting any of the scallops!

excerpts: We got the salmon ikura don and rainbow don to share.
The bowls are very similar, except the rainbow don has a variety of fish instead of just salmon.
If you like raw fish, I'd recommend the rainbow don instead of the salmon ikura don because it has more slices of fish (unless you love roe then get salmon).
All the fish were fresh and the rice was very addicting.
rainbow don.author: Julian Y.
rainbow don.review:
Super tiny place, prices are a little high, but absolutely delicious. I came in 40 minutes before they were closing for a table of two and had a very short wait.

We got the salmon ikura don and rainbow don to share. The bowls are very similar, except the rainbow don has a variety of fish instead of just salmon. If you like raw fish, I'd recommend the rainbow don instead of the salmon ikura don because it has more slices of fish (unless you love roe then get salmon). All the fish were fresh and the rice was very addicting. It comes with a side of seaweed so we made our own mini sushi wraps.

Service was great, but it should be since the restaurant isn't that big. Overall, I will definitely be back despite the high prices.

excerpts: RAINBOW DON
Three slices each for salmon, hamachi, and tuna with a big bowl of rice underneath.
You get some seaweed on the side and also it comes with a bowl of miso soup.
rainbow don.author: Diana C.
rainbow don.review:
Fresh sashimi. 20% off for their grand opening still going on this month... for how much longer, I do not know. This place is small with only a few tables. Prices are a little on the pricier side but you pay for quality freshness. Delicious but might not be as filling for some. I certainly wanted more sashimi as I neared my last piece! But my wallet didn't want to comply. They accept credit cards and they will bring around an iPad with a Square reader to take your payment. The music playing in the restaurant is also connected to the iPad though so when your payment is going through, the music will suddenly stop as it gets awkwardly silent.

RAINBOW DON
Three slices each for salmon, hamachi, and tuna with a big bowl of rice underneath. You get some seaweed on the side and also it comes with a bowl of miso soup.

excerpts: I've gotten the Rainbow don to go and while they were out of yellowtail, the woman behind the counter let me know that she subbed in some scallop and
rainbow don.author: Colleen M.
rainbow don.review:
FYI- Their prices have been going down! So stop by to see rather than look at the menus we Yelpers uploaded :)

Happy to see a newcomer on Ocean Ave, and with a pretty and clean aesthetic. I've gotten the Rainbow don to go and while they were out of yellowtail, the woman behind the counter let me know that she subbed in some scallop and ikura - a pleasant surprise!

I love chirashi bowls, and while this might not be a weekly meal for me, I'll definitely make it a point to bring my starving boyfriend here. The price point is pretty solid considering the quality and amount of raw fish. Comparable to even ordering the same amount of nigiri (raw fish on top of a little mound of rice), actually. The bowls come with a standard miso soup and some seaweed.

Service can be a little slow in the evenings if just one person is working, but they've been really friendly. You would think that it would be more crowded considering the yoga and gym crowd around the corner...

They're still working the little kinks out, but I'm digging their logo and food. Give them a try!

excerpts: But otherwise, my friend and I both stuck with the Rainbow Don option, which was delish.
The fresh salmon, hamachi, tuna sashimi pieces were massive and came with a refreshing slice of lemon each, on top of a bed of pebbled sushi rice.
A TON of rice.
rainbow don.author: Jennifer L.
rainbow don.review:
Don bowls done right! Great new chirashi spot to fill a SF void. The bud and I came here on a Saturday for a noon lunch. Zero wait. Only one other table filled in the restaurant. Parking was a bit of a nightmare bc this spot is pretty close to the 24hr fitness on Ocean. 

Anyways, within 30mins of our meal, the entire spot was packed. In fact, by the time we were leaving, there was at least 3 groups waiting to be seated. So come hungry, come early!

As for the food choices, there's just about a dozen to choose from. I was mostly disappointed bc I didn't see an option with uni + fish. I misread a previous post that said their uni specials are wknights only. AH. But otherwise, my friend and I both stuck with the Rainbow Don option, which was delish. The fresh salmon, hamachi, tuna sashimi pieces were massive and came with a refreshing slice of lemon each, on top of a bed of pebbled sushi rice. A TON of rice. We felt wasteful bc we couldn't even get through half of our rice!

With 20% off during their soft opening, it made for a great (more) budget friendly lunch option. I'd come back again on a wknight to try the uni special! 4 stars :)

excerpts: My friend and I both ordered the Rainbow Don (Hamachi (yellow tail), Ikura Roe, Tuna, Salmon, cucumbers, sushi rice, ginger, and wasabi).
The Rainbow don here is the main attraction for me.
First and foremost the presentation of the don cannot be understated.
It looked gorgeous and the various colors and textures made it pleasing to the eye.
Overall, I liked this dish a lot!
The portion size was definitely small, but the quality of the fish and overall ingredients were good.
The fishes definitely all had a good amount of fat for me and the taste of each individual fish could be distinguished.
However, I definitely think the sushi rice could have been a bit more flavored for me.
A lot of the dons are rather expensive, but they have a ton of dons here to try and the rainbow don was definitely something I enjoyed!
rainbow don.author: Anthony Y.
rainbow don.review:
A hidden don spot! (Dons are short for donburi which are Japanese rice bowls!)

Kaisen Don is a new donburi restaurant. They have a wide menu; from curry dons, to unagi dons, and even chirashi dons! (fresh fish dons). This looked like a cool new place to try!

My friend and I came at around 7pm on a Monday night. Parking here is atrocious so just a heads up! The restaurant is tiny and most of the tables were filled. Luckily there was some open spaces so my friend and I did not have to wait!

My friend and I both ordered the Rainbow Don (Hamachi (yellow tail), Ikura Roe, Tuna, Salmon, cucumbers, sushi rice, ginger, and wasabi). When you order a don, you get a complimentary miso soup! 

The miso soup was a bit on a salty side for me, but beyond that it was good classic miso soup.
The Rainbow don here is the main attraction for me. First and foremost the presentation of the don cannot be understated. It looked gorgeous and the various colors and textures made it pleasing to the eye. Overall, I liked this dish a lot! The portion size was definitely small, but the quality of the fish and overall ingredients were good. The fishes definitely all had a good amount of fat for me and the taste of each individual fish could be distinguished. However, I definitely think the sushi rice could have been a bit more flavored for me. I didn't realize it was sushi rice until 1/4 of the way in.

Overall while this was an expensive experience it was one to remember. The service here was also very good and friendly, it is something I really appreciated! A lot of the dons are rather expensive, but they have a ton of dons here to try and the rainbow don was definitely something I enjoyed!

excerpts: - Rainbow Don $19
We ordered this based off of yelp reviews but don't be fooled.
rainbow don.author: Rachel Y.
rainbow don.review:
The bf & I were pretty excited to try this place based on the reviews & the close distance from his home, but we were sadly disappointed by the quality & price.

FOOD:
- Omakase Don $29 
While this don offers a h-u-g-e variety of fish & etc, the quality doesn't deliver. The squid & scallop were also extremely disappointing - leaving a gross aftertaste in both of our mouths. The rice was ok.
- Rainbow Don $19
We ordered this based off of yelp reviews but don't be fooled. I didn't know a rainbow only had 3 colors.. but there were only 3 sashimi options offered with this & only 1 out of the 3 actually tasted decent.

ETC:
- Parking may be difficult, as it's on a very busy street.

Given that it seems like a fairly new restaurant, we might consider coming back.. or not. We'll see!

excerpts: I ordered the rainbow don, it had hamachi, salmon, and tuna.
It was on a bed of rice and came with shaved radish, some cucumber slices, and wasabi/ginger.
It was really straight forward.
I really liked the rice actually.
(When you walk in, it smells of vinegar rice.)
Their fish is fresh and it was a good enough portion to feel satisfied.
rainbow don.author: Tina Y.
rainbow don.review:
It's exactly what you would expect: a specialized menu with about 15 choices of various dons/chirashi. 

I ordered the rainbow don, it had hamachi, salmon, and tuna. It was on a bed of rice and came with shaved radish, some cucumber slices, and wasabi/ginger. It was really straight forward. I really liked the rice actually. (When you walk in, it smells of vinegar rice.) Their fish is fresh and it was a good enough portion to feel satisfied. I broke up some of my fish chunks, eating them in half piece for better portioning with rice and nori. 

I would say that their service is good. Wendy was our server and she was very friendly. I'm just confused on whether this is a place where you go up to the counter to pay... After our bowls were taken, the check never came. Our server came later with an ipad to ring us up, but to me, it's just an awkward paying experience because what if I wanted to spilt the bill differently or something. I'm not sure, next time I'll just be more direct. 

I'll definitely be back. I liked it a lot.

excerpts: Rainbow don: another mix of sashimi, very similar to the omakase don
rainbow don.author: Miffy Y.
rainbow don.review:
I think I found this place through yelp's new businesses and then followed up with looking through pictures of their amazing donburis. Four stars for their creativity and simplicity in opening a place that only serves donburis. Don't expect anything more but don't expect anything less either.

A "don" is short for Donburi which is basically meat and rice in Japanese food language. They offer around 15 different dons - ranging from the Omakase don to cooked items like Teriyaki Chicken don. 

For three girls, we ordered:
Omakase don - features a range of different sashimi at two to three pieces each: uni, hamachi, tamago, salmon, toro, tuna. 
Rainbow don: another mix of sashimi, very similar to the omakase don
Scallop Lover don: scallop sashimi with Ikura 
Unagi don: unagi with sauce over rice

We came in on a Saturday night, 630pm for three, about a 20 min wait. Their fish overall is fresh, better end of Japanese restaurants. They give you enough fish a lot of rice and ikura. We ended up taking the seaweed pieces they gave us to make Ikura nigiris. 

They are still in their soft opening phase. Very apparent with their furnishing and this place is small. Imagine a newly painted apartment living room with open kitchen split in half for you to only dine in the living room portion. Would not recommend a party of more than four. Not cozy at all, pretty bare but comfortable enough for dinner. 

Overall, I would return because I do want to try their Uni special which is only available Tues-Thurs. Otherwise, it would be a go to place for take out donburis! I would not wait more than thirty mins for this place. Just get the take out instead if you have a rainy day.

excerpts: We got the Kaisen Don #1 and the Rainbow Don.
We waited a bit for our food to come out, but it wasn't too bad.
And, we had some miso soup to sip on while we waited.
I was pleasantly surprised when we got our food.
The bowls were so beautiful, especially the Kaisen Don!
Each piece of fish seemed meticulously place.
rainbow don.author: Christine L.
rainbow don.review:
I've had good experiences with Chirashi bowls, and I was excited to try this place since it's close by and there aren't many places like it in the neighborhood. 

The place was cute! I liked the hip wooden decor and minimalistic branding. It is small, but we got there before noon, so there was still lots of seating. 

We got the Kaisen Don #1 and the Rainbow Don. We waited a bit for our food to come out, but it wasn't too bad. And, we had some miso soup to sip on while we waited. I was pleasantly surprised when we got our food. The bowls were so beautiful, especially the Kaisen Don!  Each piece of fish seemed meticulously place. I loved the little wasabi stamped with the store logo. 

They give you really crisp seaweed on the side to go with your bowl. I liked how the wasabi on the milder side, not as nose-tingling as other places,. The fish and shrimp was very fresh, not fishy at all. And it was a fair amount of fish for what we paid for. The flavor of the sushi rice was good, not overpowering, and the texture was nice and sticky. The amount of rice was typical for a Chirashi bowl. I wasn't a huge fan of the tamago as it was too sweet for me. I typically like it saltier, but it was nice and firm. It was a good amount of food for me, so I was pretty full by the end of the meal. 

The owner was very nice and came by to refill our cups whenever we ran out of tea. 

Overall, it was a great experience, and I would definitely come back again. They mentioned they would be adding more stuff to the menu in January! I'm excited to try the new stuff!

excerpts: We got the omakase don and rainbow don.
It comes with miso soup and tea gratuit.
The service was friendly and it wasn't difficult to get a seat at 6pm (nor was it hard for anyone who walked in after us to up until 7pm).
For example in the omakase don, no uni is pictured, but you do get uni in your bowl.
A simple difference like that could entirely change my decision if I want a bowl or not!
Granted that they've only been open a month and are still working a few things out, I think they have the potential to build out a strong following of Yelpers and diners soon.
rainbow don.author: Joanne Y.
rainbow don.review:
Yelp said I might like this place. On Yelp's suggestion, I was feeling a bit whimsical and had a huge craving for sushi so I decided spur of the moment to check this place out. It's kind of far if you live centrally in San Francisco, but it's right off the public transportation line so it's not a terrible trek.

For their soft opening, 20% off was an awesome deal. We got the omakase don and rainbow don. It comes with miso soup and tea gratuit. The service was friendly and it wasn't difficult to get a seat at 6pm (nor was it hard for anyone who walked in after us to up until 7pm). One thing I loved was the amount of fish that you get on top of the chirashi bowl - Kaisen Don is by far one of the more generous places. As for improvements: the rice (as others have mentioned) and quality of wasabi are in need of help. I'm kind of picky about my rice, but I think it could have used more seasoning or "sushi rice flavor". The menu pictures also don't exactly match what you get... For example in the omakase don, no uni is pictured, but you do get uni in your bowl. A simple difference like that could entirely change my decision if I want a bowl or not! Granted that they've only been open a month and are still working a few things out, I think they have the potential to build out a strong following of Yelpers and diners soon. :)

excerpts: I got the rainbow don, but I switched out the tuna for more salmon sashimi.
The quality of the fish was top notch!
I could tell the fish was super clean and fresh.
There wasn't any fishy smell or taste at all.
Would definitely recommend trying out this hidden gem!
rainbow don.author: Eunice C.
rainbow don.review: This was such an unexpected find! So glad that my sisters and I decided to try this place. This restaurant specializes in Kaisen don's (hence the name of the restaurant). Kaisen dons are basically rice bowls with different types of sashimi on top. I got the rainbow don, but I switched out the tuna for more salmon sashimi. The quality of the fish was top notch! I could tell the fish was super clean and fresh. There wasn't any fishy smell or taste at all. Would definitely recommend trying out this hidden gem!

excerpts: My friends and I all ordered the same bowl, Rainbow Don.
rainbow don.author: Autumn L.
rainbow don.review:
My friends and I all ordered the same bowl, Rainbow Don. 

Price: $$
You will end up paying about the same, if not more, for a 9 piece sashimi assortment. (and it usually does not come with rice and miso soup) For some people, one bowl might not be filling enough.

Fish: Good Quality
We expected red tuna to come with our order. We were shocked when we got chu toro instead. I'm not sure if we just lucky. The other photos I see on Yelp are red tuna. They gave us SO MUCH RICE. The rice to fish proportion didn't seem right.  

Venue: Small
The restaurant itself is small so please go earlier and avoid dinner rush hours.

Service: Good
The server was very attentive. She actually recommended that we all order something different so we can have variety. 

I highly recommend that you give this place a try. The quality and service are both good. The only downside is that you might walk out hungry with just one bowl.

excerpts: If you're a hamachi lover like me, I would totally recommend the rainbow don!
The hamachi melted in my mouth and was super fresh.
The salmon didn't really have that glistening effect that I usually see on fatty salmon but the quality of it was pretty ok.
I think the lemon helped make it more tasteful.
Ehh I would probably skip the seaweed they give on a little tray.
It was pretty stale and hard to bite into.
I tried to bite a small piece of it, but it got stuck on my teeth LOL.
The rice was pretty good too!
Idk if they only put rice vinegar to it
but it was pretty tasty with the fish.
My friend's order didn't have enough fish for hers
I think she only had like 6 pieces compared to mine?
I forgot her order!
Either way, I think people should check this place out before the 20% off soft opening coupon expires because this place is pretty expensive!
I do like how they have a sashimi bowl place here that I wouldn't need to go to downtown and try the Grubbies.
Other than that, I don't think I would come back unless I really REALLY want to treat myself out!
rainbow don.author: Sarah F.
rainbow don.review: W O W the quality of the fish here is superb. If you're a hamachi lover like me, I would totally recommend the rainbow don! The hamachi melted in my mouth and was super fresh. The salmon didn't really have that glistening effect that I usually see on fatty salmon but the quality of it was pretty ok. I think the lemon helped make it more tasteful. Ehh I would probably skip the seaweed they give on a little tray. It was pretty stale and hard to bite into. I tried to bite a small piece of it, but it got stuck on my teeth LOL. The rice was pretty good too! Idk if they only put rice vinegar to it but it was pretty tasty with the fish. My friend's order didn't have enough fish for hers :/ I think she only had like 6 pieces compared to mine? I forgot her order! Either way, I think people should check this place out before the 20% off soft opening coupon expires because this place is pretty expensive! I do like how they have a sashimi bowl place here that I wouldn't need to go to downtown and try the Grubbies. Other than that, I don't think I would come back unless I really REALLY want to treat myself out!

excerpts: so we ordered three: two Rainbow Don and one Salmon Scallop Don.
The bowls were a good size and served with a side of seaweed for you to DIY.
The rice was not bad, and the perfect amount to place with each piece of fish on seaweed.
Fish and seaweed was pretty decent too.
We also decided to try their specials of the day: Scallop Burger and Kaisen Spoon.
The spoon was good, however I couldn't taste the uni on the spoon, mostly oyster - but still tasted
okay.
The miso soup that came with the chirashi bowls were like any miso soup served in town and probably not homemade.
The scallop burger was extremely tiny and was one piece of scallop cut in half to fit the uni and truffles.
The truffle flavor overpowered the scallop and uni so I didn't realize the scallop was so sweet until I had it in my chirashi bowl.
Not the best I've had, but decent.
rainbow don.author: Amanda C.
rainbow don.review: Came here on a Friday night with three others, and since they didn't do reservations, we were expecting a wait. Upon arrival, we almost missed the entire restaurant because it is a very small shop in the middle of the block fitting 20 people maximum. Small spot, but surprisingly no wait. We got there and were seated within 5 minutes. There was only 1 server working the whole floor, but she was friendly. They're known for their chirashi bowl so we ordered three: two Rainbow Don and one Salmon Scallop Don. The bowls were a good size and served with a side of seaweed for you to DIY. The rice was not bad, and the perfect amount to place with each piece of fish on seaweed. Fish and seaweed was pretty decent too. We also decided to try their specials of the day: Scallop Burger and Kaisen Spoon. The spoon was good, however I couldn't taste the uni on the spoon, mostly oyster - but still tasted okay. The miso soup that came with the chirashi bowls were like any miso soup served in town and probably not homemade. The scallop burger was extremely tiny and was one piece of scallop cut in half to fit the uni and truffles. The truffle flavor overpowered the scallop and uni so I didn't realize the scallop was so sweet until I had it in my chirashi bowl. Not the best I've had, but decent.

excerpts: and I ordered the Rainbow Don.
The fish was very fresh but unfortunately, the portions don't match the price.
My girlfriend gets full pretty easily but she ended up still being slightly hungry.
Personally, I think I might have needed two to fill me up.
It's about 3 pieces of each fish in the don.
I know in order for them to have premium fish quality, they have to charge higher than other places but the prices are still too high.
For this specific order, I still ended up spending around $30, even with the 20% discount they offered.
I don't think I could fathom the thought of coming here without that discount.
rainbow don.author: R C.
rainbow don.review:
Picked up some dinner here a couple weeks ago. Small place with a couple of tables, probably seats around 15 people. The inside is nice and clean albeit a little plain. I ordered takeout for my girlfriend and I though since it was a cold night and I wanted to get home quickly to watch the Warriors game. The guy who took our takeout order was nice and gave us ample time to pick what we wanted.

I don't 100% remember what she ordered but I believe it was the Kaisen Don #1 and I ordered the Rainbow Don. The fish was very fresh but unfortunately, the portions don't match the price. My girlfriend gets full pretty easily but she ended up still being slightly hungry. Personally, I think I might have needed two to fill me up. It's about 3 pieces of each fish in the don. I know in order for them to have premium fish quality, they have to charge higher than other places but the prices are still too high. For this specific order, I still ended up spending around $30, even with the 20% discount they offered. I don't think I could fathom the thought of coming here without that discount. It honestly had me craving some Poki Time at Westlake just because the fish portion at Kaisen Don just wasn't enough.

I'm hoping that Kaisen Don can turn it around though. They have a great product but the prices are just too steep. I wish them the best!

excerpts: I ordered the Rainbow Don and asked if I can replace one of the item with something else since I'm not a fan of tuna.
They were very flexible with my request, so I got more salmon and hamachi.
The fish were absolutely fresh and thick--just how I like it!
The rice was perfectly cook.
Their miso soup was good as well, not salty like most places.
We also ordered the Uni Special, it was so fresh literally melted in my mouth.
Will definitely come back for more.
rainbow don.author: Mimi Y.
rainbow don.review: I ordered the Rainbow Don and asked if I can replace one of the item with something else since I'm not a fan of tuna. They were very flexible with my request, so I got more salmon and hamachi. The fish were absolutely fresh and thick--just how I like it! The rice was perfectly cook. Their miso soup was good as well, not salty like most places. We also ordered the Uni Special, it was so fresh literally melted in my mouth. Will definitely come back for more.

excerpts: We ordered Omasake and Rainbow Don.
The fish are very fresh and rice is well prepped.
We also order the Hamachi Karma but was a bit undercook, which we sent back to get it steamed.
I would say its bit on the pricy side, but you get good quality fish and food.
rainbow don.author: Jeff L.
rainbow don.review: Went there for lunch and we were seated  right away. Its a new place so its very clean. The service was good and very welcoming. We ordered Omasake and Rainbow Don. The fish are very fresh and rice is well prepped. We also order the Hamachi Karma but was a bit undercook, which we sent back to get it steamed. I would say its bit on the pricy side, but you get good quality fish and food.

excerpts: We ordered a Kaisen Don #1, Hamachi don and a rainbow don.
Fish were fresh and nice portion.
I like how they serve the seaweed on a side and I can assemble my own sushi roll.
I will definitely come back again to try other don!
rainbow don.author: Vic L.
rainbow don.review: Very impressed with the quality of the fish! We ordered a Kaisen Don #1, Hamachi don and a rainbow don. Fish were fresh and nice portion. I like how they serve the seaweed on a side and I can assemble my own sushi roll. I will definitely come back again to try other don!

excerpts: We usually get the rainbow don, tuna don, chirashi and gyu-don.
rainbow don.author: Joy S.
rainbow don.review: Love this place! This is our go to Japanese place. We did noticed that the portions have gotten smaller which bums me out. We usually get the rainbow don, tuna don, chirashi and gyu-don.

excerpts: I recommend the Rainbow Don
rainbow don.author: John G.
rainbow don.review: The fish is so fresh.  I hope they keep the quality of the fish up because that is key.  The high prices are worth it as long as the quality stays where it has been. I recommend the Rainbow Don

excerpts: I got the Rainbow Don and had approximately 9-10 pieces of fish and some ikura sprinkled on top.
Presentation is done really well.
It's a tiny spot but nice for a neighborhood meal with a friend.
rainbow don.author: Jessica H.
rainbow don.review: Went here for their soft opening. They had 20% off. The fish is alright. The portions aren't too huge so it's not like you will stuffed. I got the Rainbow Don and had approximately 9-10 pieces of fish and some ikura sprinkled on top. Presentation is done really well. It's a tiny spot but nice for a neighborhood meal with a friend.

excerpts: We ordered scallop lover and rainbow don.
rainbow don.author: Michelle T.
rainbow don.review:
The wait for Saturday lunch was short, about 5 mins. We ordered scallop lover and rainbow don. Food came with hot tea and hot miso soup (yums). 

Both dons came with a good amount of warm sushi rice. The presentation was beautiful (should've taken pictures but too hungry!) The fish and scallops were really fresh! No fishy taste or random chewy bits. The hot tea kept flowing throughout the meal. No complaints. 

For non raw fish eaters, they have a selection of cooked dons which looked equally as impressive.

excerpts: I ordered the rainbow don and added an amai ebi to my don.
My amai ebi was really small and what made it worst is that my friend got the exact same thing as me, rainbow don with amai ebi but her amai ebi was a regular size.
I was upset that I got a really small ebi
but my friend got a regular size and she was sitting right next to me.
We are paying for the same price, so how come my ebi was so small.
They should just give us the same size or add another small amai ebi on my bowl to make it seem like all the portions of the rice bowls are the same.
rainbow don.author: Katie Y.
rainbow don.review:
The fish was ok and fresh which is good. I think everything is overpriced for the quality of the fish.

The worst was the sushi rice. It was just plain rice which is a big disappointment. It felt like I was just having a big bowl of white rice with some fish on top. The rice was missing the vinegar, sugar and salt. The basic ingredients that you will have in sushi rice. 

I ordered the rainbow don and added an amai ebi to my don. My amai ebi was really small and what made it worst is that my friend got the exact same thing as me, rainbow don with amai ebi but her amai ebi was a regular size. I was upset that I got a really small ebi but my friend got a regular size and she was sitting right next to me. We are paying for the same price, so how come my ebi was so small. They should just give us the same size or add another small amai ebi on my bowl to make it seem like all the portions of the rice bowls are the same. But they charged us $10 for two amai ebi. 

The place is really small and they had one server working. It wasn't really busy the day we went and the server was nice and he refilled our teas from time to time. 

Overall, I just feel like everything is overpriced even with the 20% off for soft opening.

excerpts: My partner and I shared a Rainbow Don and a Beef Curry Don.
Both were excellent.
Each bowl also came with miso soup.
Highly recommend and will be going back soon!
rainbow don.author: Garrett L.
rainbow don.review: What a great new restaurant on Ocean Ave! The best thing about this place is how fresh the sashimi tastes. No other Japanese restaurant in this area is on the same level. Prices are very reasonable for what you're getting. Also, the service is super friendly. My partner and I shared a Rainbow Don and a Beef Curry Don. Both were excellent. Each bowl also came with miso soup. Highly recommend and will be going back soon!

excerpts: I got the rainbow don with tuna, hamachi, salmon and salmon roe.
The fish was fresh and the meal came with free tea and miso soup--nothing too special but nice on a chilly day.
The menu is pretty limited, with only sushi rice available as a base.
It sounds like they plan to add more choices in the future.
If the quality stays good we're looking forward to making this place a frequent stop for dinner.
rainbow don.author: Andrea K.
rainbow don.review: Just stopped by here during their soft opening and I'm so glad that we have a decent sushi place in our neighborhood!  Hubby got the hamachi bowl--large slabs served with tamago, salmon roe and cucumber.  I got the rainbow don with tuna, hamachi, salmon and salmon roe.  The fish was fresh and the meal came with free tea and miso soup--nothing too special but nice on a chilly day.  The menu is pretty limited, with only sushi rice available as a base.  It sounds like they plan to add more choices in the future.  If the quality stays good we're looking forward to making this place a frequent stop for dinner.

excerpts: The concept of this place is not bad since they are mainly serving the fresh fish/bowls or hot bowls such as unagi don, salmon ochazuke don, gyu don and etc.
If you like chirashi-
I recommend coming here!
For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls
but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.
gyu don.author: Sammi L.
gyu don.review:
いらっしゃいませ！

Kaisen DON defines Chirashi bowls to me. Came here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was packed. Every table were seated and I see that every table had at least one Omakase Don- so I knew I had to order that! I ordered the Omakase Don along with their daily special: Truffle with Scallops. 

Omakase Don: the bowl have 12 pc of fresh sashimi and sushi rice/ comes with seaweed and wasabi/soy sauce.

Truffle with Scallops: 4 pcs of scallops topped with tobiko and truffle

Overall, the sashimi was fresh but the cut can be more generous. The concept of this place is not bad since they are mainly serving the fresh fish/bowls or hot bowls such as unagi don, salmon ochazuke don, gyu don and etc. If you like chirashi- I recommend coming here! For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.

excerpts: Gyu Don (thin beef, onion, tamago)($12.95) - to supplement the uni
, I ordered one of these.
The tamago was tasty, even if it looked more like cheese.
The beef was nice and tender and they give you a decent amount vs. rice.
gyu don.author: Audrey H.
gyu don.review:
A hidden gem for good donburi AND UNI!  Came here for a later lunch on a Saturday (1pm-ish).

Venue / Service: on the smaller side, the biggest table probably seats 4 people and fits probably no more than 20 people.  B/c the kitchen is small, food does take a bit on the longer side, but not long enough that you start to get impatient.

Food: in general, the donburis are well portioned, in fact larger than I've seen at most places.  Enough protein vs. rice and bowl sizes are good enough to fill the stomach of a hungry guy.
-- Santa Barbara Uni / Half Tray (~$30) - came here mainly for this since we love uni.  A half tray is around 5 pieces, which are placed on slices of cucumber and served with wasabi and pieces of nori.  We basically placed pieces of uni in the nori with a bit of wasabi, which I think was the best way to enjoy the taste cleanly.  Uni was pretty fresh and sweet (being from Santa Barbara); definitely worth the trip for!

-- Gyu Don (thin beef, onion, tamago)($12.95) - to supplement the uni, I ordered one of these.  The tamago was tasty, even if it looked more like cheese.  The beef was nice and tender and they give you a decent amount vs. rice.  Wish there were more veggies / onions, but the taste was pretty good.

My date had the Unagi Don (BBQ eel, seaweed, pickle)($15.95), which was also quite tasty.  A bit too much of the sauce on it, but the eel was nicely cooked and was a pretty big piece.

All in all, we weren't disappointed after driving out of SF just to try their uni and the donburis.  Price was a bit high, but I think my date and I would make a trip out again here.

excerpts: We ordered an Omakase Don ($26.95) and a Gyu Don (13.95).
The Omakase Don had various types of fish, but it was your basics (tuna, salmon, hamachi, etc.).
The Gyu Don is pretty much a beef sukiyaki bowl.
The fish is fresh and sukiyaki is well made, not too salty and not too sweet.
However, there is a problem with both of these bowls - too much rice!
There was so much rice in the Omakase Don that half of the bowl was still full.
There was a lot of filler on the Omakase Don
gyu don.author: Nicholas H.
gyu don.review:
There aren't many chirashi places in San Francisco, so I was excited to see this place in my recommendations. TL;DR Despite the positive//negative reviews, try this place for yourself because you won't regret it!

It's a small restaurant with seating for only ~20 people so the wait may be longer than usual. I went in around 8:30 on a Friday and waited till 8:55 before getting a table for 2.

We ordered an Omakase Don ($26.95) and a Gyu Don (13.95). The Omakase Don had various types of fish, but it was your basics (tuna, salmon, hamachi, etc.). The Gyu Don is pretty much a beef sukiyaki bowl. The fish is fresh and sukiyaki is well made, not too salty and not too sweet. However, there is a problem with both of these bowls - too much rice! There was so much rice in the Omakase Don that half of the bowl was still full. There was a lot of filler on the Omakase Don - I truly hope they decide to add more fish on it, then the $26.95 would justify it.

Overall, I had a great experience here, the employees are friendly and pretty hardworking. I think that only two people work here and it can get overwhelming for them. If you're the manager, help them out and hire one more person!

If you like chirashi-
I recommend coming here!
For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls
but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.

unagi don.review:
いらっしゃいませ！

Kaisen DON defines Chirashi bowls to me. Came here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was packed. Every table were seated and I see that every table had at least one Omakase Don- so I knew I had to order that! I ordered the Omakase Don along with their daily special: Truffle with Scallops.

excerpts: We order Rainbow Bowl and Kaisen Don, Unagi Don and Sashimi.
The food was delicious and looks nice.
It's a little pricey but good experience to try .
unagi don.author: Lily L.
unagi don.review:
We came on a Sunday to eat lunch, it's a small restaurant. The waiter was attentive to our needed and refills our tea.
We order Rainbow Bowl and Kaisen Don, Unagi Don and Sashimi. The food was delicious and looks nice. 
It's a little pricey but good experience to try .

excerpts: My date had the Unagi Don (BBQ eel, seaweed, pickle)($15.95), which was also quite tasty.
unagi don.author: Audrey H.
unagi don.review:
A hidden gem for good donburi AND UNI!  Came here for a later lunch on a Saturday (1pm-ish).

Venue / Service: on the smaller side, the biggest table probably seats 4 people and fits probably no more than 20 people.  B/c the kitchen is small, food does take a bit on the longer side, but not long enough that you start to get impatient.

excerpts:
Scallop Lover don: scallop sashimi with Ikura 
Unagi don: unagi with sauce over rice
unagi don.author: Miffy Y.
unagi don.review:
I think I found this place through yelp's new businesses and then followed up with looking through pictures of their amazing donburis. Four stars for their creativity and simplicity in opening a place that only serves donburis. Don't expect anything more but don't expect anything less either.

A "don" is short for Donburi which is basically meat and rice in Japanese food language. They offer around 15 different dons - ranging from the Omakase don to cooked items like Teriyaki Chicken don. 

For three girls, we ordered:
Omakase don - features a range of different sashimi at two to three pieces each: uni, hamachi, tamago, salmon, toro, tuna. 
Rainbow don: another mix of sashimi, very similar to the omakase don
Scallop Lover don: scallop sashimi with Ikura 
Unagi don: unagi with sauce over rice

We came in on a Saturday night, 630pm for three, about a 20 min wait. Their fish overall is fresh, better end of Japanese restaurants. They give you enough fish a lot of rice and ikura. We ended up taking the seaweed pieces they gave us to make Ikura nigiris. 

They are still in their soft opening phase. Very apparent with their furnishing and this place is small. Imagine a newly painted apartment living room with open kitchen split in half for you to only dine in the living room portion. Would not recommend a party of more than four. Not cozy at all, pretty bare but comfortable enough for dinner. 

Overall, I would return because I do want to try their Uni special which is only available Tues-Thurs. Otherwise, it would be a go to place for take out donburis! I would not wait more than thirty mins for this place. Just get the take out instead if you have a rainy day.

excerpts: Tried the uni taco, unagi don, and truffle salmon don.
All delicious.
unagi don.author: Gina R.
unagi don.review:
I almost don't want to review them because I don't want it to be hella packed next time I come...but it's amazing! Presentation is on point. Everything is clearly prepared with precision and care. And the flavors are equally amazing. 

Tried the uni taco, unagi don, and truffle salmon don. All delicious. Chirashi bowls served with nori strips.

I'll be back.

excerpts: I ordered the scallop don, while he ordered the unagi don.
unagi don.author: Leslie C.
unagi don.review:
Not bad!

Came here with a party of 4 a little after they had opened for the evening and we were seated right away. I ordered the scallop don, while he ordered the unagi don. There were a few bowls that they were out of, so be prepared with 2nd and 3rd choices when you order.

All of our orders came with miso soup to start. My scallops tasted fresh and there was enough protein to satisfy me. The cooked donburi bowls take a bit longer to prepare (obviously), and they don't bring everything out at the same time. Service was good. Overall, would come back.

excerpts: The unagi don, best one I have had in the city.
unagi don.author: Deb L.
unagi don.review:
Really fresh!  You pay a little more than usual, but it's worth it! 

The unagi don, best one I have had in the city.

excerpts: If you're not a fan of raw fish, their unagi don is made to order and delicious (it can be too much of the same texture/taste for some due to the quantity you're getting).
unagi don.author: Eric L.
unagi don.review:
This is one of the hidden new gems on Ocean Ave. Fresh, high quality sashimi for relatively affordable price is a rarity and this place is that.

It's a small place with a small staff so service and wait times reflect that nature. It also smells strongly like the ocean (brininess). 

For those trying this place for the first time, I suggest going hard and trying their omakase don. If you're not a fan of raw fish, their unagi don is made to order and delicious (it can be too much of the same texture/taste for some due to the quantity you're getting). The salmon ochazuke is also a good Asian comfort dish, it's very remeniscent of porridge; something I would order if I was sick. 

All in all, I think this place is worth trying and has become one of my go to places for good sashimi that isn't a Michelin star restaurant. Plus, you can order a goddamn tray of uni here, please.

excerpts: The kids loved their Unagi Don and Chashu Don.
Nice service and casual atmosphere.
Parking in the area is also easy which is a plus.
Will come again.
unagi don.author: Michael C.
unagi don.review: Everything was fresh and very tasty.  Great presentation of the sashimi.  The kids loved their Unagi Don and Chashu Don.  Nice service and casual atmosphere.  Parking in the area is also easy which is a plus.  Will come again.

excerpts: Other items ordered were the Kaisen spoon (oyster topped with uni), salmon ikura don, and chashu don.
chashu don.author: Bonnie T.
chashu don.review:
A pretty decent place to get your Chirashi don fix. The portions are perfect. Not too big and not too small. They're also really generous with the rice. Miso soup was complimentary. However, the prices are a little high. 

Place is pretty small and it threw me off when there was a very strong fish smell as soon as I walked in. My jean jacket still has the smell of fish stuck to it. 

My favorite item that was ordered would be the uni scallop burger. The uni scallop burger has black truffle sauce stuffed inside. Each burger is $10. This item isn't listed on the actual menu but is written on a very small chalkboard near the cash register. If it wasn't for yelp, I wouldn't have known this item existed. 

Other items ordered were the Kaisen spoon (oyster topped with uni), salmon ikura don, and chashu don. 

Salmon ikura don was about $20. It was good but I don't think it was worth $20!? Luckily, there was a 10% discount for the yelp check in!

excerpts: Ordered Chashu Don, Hamachi Taco, Salmon Truffle Don.
Free edamame with check-in.
Service was very attentive and courteous.
Food was tasty but portions were small for the price.
I was about 80% full after eating the Chashu Don and Hamachi Taco.
chashu don.author: Cathrin P C.
chashu don.review: Ordered Chashu Don, Hamachi Taco, Salmon Truffle Don. Free edamame with check-in. Service was very attentive and courteous. Food was tasty but portions were small for the price. I was about 80% full after eating the Chashu Don and Hamachi Taco.

excerpts: The kids loved their Unagi Don and Chashu Don.
Nice service and casual atmosphere.
Parking in the area is also easy which is a plus.
Will come again.
chashu don.author: Michael C.
chashu don.review: Everything was fresh and very tasty.  Great presentation of the sashimi.  The kids loved their Unagi Don and Chashu Don.  Nice service and casual atmosphere.  Parking in the area is also easy which is a plus.  Will come again.

excerpts: We also tried the salmon ochazuke
and it was ok.
The salmon was a bit salty
but it was still decent.
Probably wouldn't be something I order again
salmon ochazuke.author: Stella J.
salmon ochazuke.review:
I had heard so much about Kaisen DON and was so excited to try it! I was meeting up with friends and we decided to eat here on a whim. We got here right when it opened. They informed us that they didn't have any blue Fin tuna at all today so they would be replacing the bowls with tuna with other fish. The menu is quite extensive in terms of the bowls they have and they have a rotating menu of appetizers and specials! 

I opted for the truffle salmon don and it had 6 pieces of seared salmon topped with truffle sauce. It also came with cucumbers , tamago and some seaweed on the side. The rice was nicely seasoned and when you wrapped the rice, seaweed and salmon together it was delicious! We also tried the salmon ochazuke and it was ok. The salmon was a bit salty but it was still decent. Probably wouldn't be something I order again but I would come back for all the other bowls.

This place is def not on the cheap side, but if you like good quality fish this place is a good option. Can't wait to come back to try the other dons.

Total for 3: $95

excerpts: The concept of this place is not bad since they are mainly serving the fresh fish/bowls or hot bowls such as unagi don, salmon ochazuke don, gyu don and etc.
If you like chirashi-
I recommend coming here!
For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls
but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.
salmon ochazuke.author: Sammi L.
salmon ochazuke.review:
いらっしゃいませ！

Kaisen DON defines Chirashi bowls to me. Came here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was packed. Every table were seated and I see that every table had at least one Omakase Don- so I knew I had to order that! I ordered the Omakase Don along with their daily special: Truffle with Scallops. 

Omakase Don: the bowl have 12 pc of fresh sashimi and sushi rice/ comes with seaweed and wasabi/soy sauce.

Truffle with Scallops: 4 pcs of scallops topped with tobiko and truffle

Overall, the sashimi was fresh but the cut can be more generous. The concept of this place is not bad since they are mainly serving the fresh fish/bowls or hot bowls such as unagi don, salmon ochazuke don, gyu don and etc. If you like chirashi- I recommend coming here! For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.

excerpts: The salmon ochazuke is also a good Asian comfort dish, it's very remeniscent of porridge; something I would order if I was sick.
salmon ochazuke.author: Eric L.
salmon ochazuke.review:
This is one of the hidden new gems on Ocean Ave. Fresh, high quality sashimi for relatively affordable price is a rarity and this place is that.

It's a small place with a small staff so service and wait times reflect that nature. It also smells strongly like the ocean (brininess). 

For those trying this place for the first time, I suggest going hard and trying their omakase don. If you're not a fan of raw fish, their unagi don is made to order and delicious (it can be too much of the same texture/taste for some due to the quantity you're getting). The salmon ochazuke is also a good Asian comfort dish, it's very remeniscent of porridge; something I would order if I was sick. 

All in all, I think this place is worth trying and has become one of my go to places for good sashimi that isn't a Michelin star restaurant. Plus, you can order a goddamn tray of uni here, please.

salmon ochazuke.author: Alice C.
salmon ochazuke.review: Yum! Reminds me of the little mom and pop shops in Japan. The scallops and uni were sweet and served at the perfect temperature. Portions are huge. The salmon ochazuke needed a little bit of soy sauce but it was the perfect comfort food for rainy SF weather. I will be back (and bringing friends!) to try their sashimi.

sprite.author: Jeffrey W.
sprite.review: New place utilizing a small space very efficiently. Staff is nice and courteous, a good first impression. Simple dinner to enjoy, would definitely come again!  The ingredients all tasted fresh and the rice was cooked well. Yes, rice was cooked well, cooking rice is art. I like it a certain way, not too soft and not too hard. Maybe some alcohol in the future? LoL hopefully the city will allow them :) haha I'll enjoy sprite in the meantime here, or some tea.
